did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle:
Markham Starr collection
2005-2019
did.physdesc: 18 documents : digital, pdf, doc, xls, and txt
56 video files : digital, mov, mp4, m2t, m2ts, avi

corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Collection of 1747 digital files of graphic, moving image, sound recording, and manuscript format documentary works created by Markham Starr and four of his published monographs. The collection primarily documents northeastern fishermen and the fishing industry. Some records also document farming and dairy production. A majority of the works are part of larger themed documentary projects, and others are independent works.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The collection was acquired from Starr in five separate accruals, 2013-2020. The film in Series 2 ('Scalloping on the Mister G') was originally received as a DVD and Starr delivered a replacement digital file to the archive in February 2021.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Markham Starr collection was minimally processed by Charles Hosale between November 2020 and February 2021. Prior to that, Bert Lyons processed afc2013031_dc001 (series 1, the 2013 accession) in 2013. Julia Kim modified filenames in afc2013031_dc004 (series 4, the 2019 accrual) at the time of acquisition. In general, the other files have not been arranged or renamed. Charles Hosale retroactively assigned AFC "dc" ID numbers in 2020. Prior to 2020 the individual accruals did not have unique identifiers. Some records that had been separated into the case file after acquisition were reintegrated into the collection by Charles Hosale in December 2020. The digital accruals were processed into individual archival information packages (AIPs) in March 2022. The paper monographs were minimally processed prior to 2020. See the series-level Scope and Content and Arrangement notes for more specific information concerning each record group.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p:
The materials in the collection are governed by copyright for a term of 15 years after acquisition. When the term has expired the materials are designated to the public domain. While the materials are still under the 15-year term, their reuse is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0) license
https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/4.0/
. The published works may be governed by separate copyright terms or other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
The Markham Starr collection is open to research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact
Restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Markham Starr collection (AFC 2013/031), American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Markham Starr is a documentary photographer, writer, and filmmaker from Connecticut. He is active in the northeastern United States. His primary interests are fisherman and the fishing industry, and has also documented farming and dairy production, among other arts and trades. His particular focus is documenting industries and individuals experiencing change due to industrialization, technological advancements, globalization, or government regulation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection of 1747 digital files of graphic, moving image, sound recording, and manuscript format documentary works created by Markham Starr, and 4 of Starr's published monographs. The collection primarily documents northeastern United States fisherman and the fishing industry. Some records also document farming and dairy production. Starr created the records in the collection between 2005 and 2019. The works often focus on individuals and businesses experiencing change due to industrialization, technological advancements, globalization, or government regulation. Many of the moving image, sound recording, and manuscript works feature first-person narratives from interview subjects. The discussions concern their experience as workers and the ways their work has changed during their careers. Some of the records feature detailed discussions and demonstrations of technical processes and skilled techniques. The graphic materials depict individuals at work or in portrait,worksites, and trade tools, machinery, and implements. A majority of the works are associated with one of Starr's larger themed documentary projects, but the sound recordings and some of the moving images are independent works.

Starr selected works from his projects to donate to the American Folklife Center. Besides those that stand alone, the records are drawn from six themed documentary projects. The names of the projects and the years they were conducted are:

list.item:
End of the Line: Closing the Last Sardine Cannery in America
, March 2010.

Finest Kind: The Lobstermen of Corea Maine
, June and July 2010.

Against the Tide: The Commercial Fishermen of Point Judith RI
, 2005-2013.

Down On The Farm: The Last Dairy Farms of North Stonington
, 2007-2010.

In History's Wake: The Last Trap Fishermen of RI
, 2008-2018.

Voices From The Waterfront: Portrait of the New Bedford Fishing Industry
, 2009.

scopecontent.p: These projects resulted in published books, which are titled with the same names. Digital drafts or final publications of the books are included in this collection's manuscript materials. Additionally, some of the titles have physical printed copies also included in the collection (series 6). Starr's descriptions of these projects can be found in the manuscripts, especially the books.

The bulk of the collection is graphic materials and moving images. The graphic materials are all associated with one of the six documentary projects and are grouped by project. The moving images are roughly divided into two equal groupings: those that are part of
In History's Wake: The Last Trap Fishermen of RI
, and those that are independent works. All but one of the moving images concerns fishing and fishermen - the outlier is about a Preston, Connecticut farmer and his family dairy farm. Most of the fishing films, including the independent works, are shot in Rhode Island and concern the region's fish industry. The films vary in length from short to feature length. The sound recordings are interviews with Rhode Island trap fishermen; however Starr indicates that these recordings were conducted separately from his
In History's Wake: The Last Trap Fishermen of RI
project.

Starr's manuscripts are either associated with a documentary project or are descriptive aids for the collection. The descriptive aids are spreadsheets and text documents and contain item level information for each file. Archivists repurposed, with very minimal edits, much of Starr's guides into the titles and item-level Scope and Content notes in this finding aid. The guides contain some additional information such as locations and camera equipment used. The descriptive documents in each series are:

list.item:
Series 2. 2015 accrual (afc2013031_dc002):
"Against the Tide The Commercial Fishermen of Point Judith RI.xls,"
"Down on the Farm The Last Dairy Farms of North Stonington.xls,"
"In Historys Wake The Last Trap Fishermen of RI.xls,"
and
"Voices From the Waterfront Portraits From the New Bedford Fishing Industry.xls"

Series 5. 2020 accrual (afc2013031_dc005):
"Descriptions of the films on this hard drive.txt"

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Markham Starr collection is arranged in 6 series. Series 1 through Series 5 each correspond to one accrual from the donor. Series 6 is a small grouping of four of Starr's printed books. The series are:

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

Starr, Markham. Finest kind : the lobstermen of Corea, portrait of a down east fishing village. 2011.

did.unittitle:
Series 1. 2013 accrual:
End of the Line
and
Finest Kind
files,
March 1, 2010 through March 30, 2010
,
June 28 2010 through July 30 2010
did.physdesc: 822 TIFF, 2 jpg, 2 pdf, 2 xls, and 1 docx

scopecontent.p:
Accrual is 824 images, 2 corresponding spreadsheets, 2 book pdfs, and 1 manuscript. The files concern two of Starr's documentary projects:
End of the Line: Closing the Last Sardine Cannery in America
and
Finest Kind: The Lobstermen of Corea Maine
. The photos are from two documentary trips; the Lobstermen photos are from June and July 2010 and the Cannery photos are from March 2010, primarily the 29th and 30th. See the Biographical Note for further descriptions of the projects. The photos generally depict subjects at work, tools and implements, and worksites. Every photo has an item level description, which are saved with the photos in two spreadsheets - see this series' Arrangement Note for more information. The PDF 'Finest Kind The Lobstermen of Corea Maine.pdf' is a copy of Starr's book by the same name. In addition to copies of the photographs, it contains transcribed interviews with a dozen fisherman and their families, extensive information about the lobster fishing trade and industry, and descriptions of Starr's project. The PDF 'The Last Sardine The Closing of the Stinson Cannery.pdf' only contains copies of Starr's photographs. The word document 'afc2013031_ms01.docx' is Starr's description of the Cannery documentary project.

arrangement.p:
Starr assigned unique IDs to the images in this accrual. The unique ids are a sequential number starting from zero. The file 'manifest_ph0001-ph0336_inventory.xls' contains the Starr's descriptions for the
Cannery
project photos, and 'manifest_ph0337-ph0824_inventory.xls' contains his descriptions for the
Lobsterman
photos. The unique IDs match the descriptions to filenames. Dates, when provided in the spreadsheets, appear to be inaccurate. The images' Exif metadata appears to have more reliable date information. The files are all in one folder.

processinfo.p: The accrual was initially processed by Bert Lyons in 2013. During processing, American Folklife Center staff prepended "afc2013031_ph" to the photo filenames and renamed the digital manuscript. Charles Hosale added the PDF files to the folder in November 2020. The PDFs had previously been stored separately.

did.unittitle:
Subseries 1.
End of the Line: Closing the Last Sardine Cannery in America
files,
March 1, 2010 through March 30, 2010

scopecontent.p: Photographs created during Starr's visit to the Stinson Cannery in 2010. Also included is one manuscript document containing Starr's description of the photography project, a PDF containing copies of the photographs, and one inventory spreadsheet containing descriptive data for every photo.

arrangement.p: The digital files on disk have not been rearranged from their original order. The manuscript files have been described in alphabetical order in the finding aid and the photographs are listed in numerical order by ID number. The photographs' titles and ID numbers are copied from Starr's item level metadata in the photo inventory "manifest_ph0001-ph0336_inventory.xls". The descriptions are used as titles. If a description was too long to be an effective title archivists shortened it and recorded the original description in the item's Scope and Content note. The dates come from the photographs' EXIF metadata, except where that data is clearly inaccurate. In those cases archivists estimated an accurate date. See the inventory and files' metadata for more context.

A Description of the Stinson Cannery Photo Project,
March 2010

The Last Sardine: The Closing of the Stinson Cannery
,

did.unittitle:
Photo inventory,
March 2010

Part of the village of Prospect Harbor, Maine as seen from across the harbor,
March 28, 2010

Architectural detail on a home in Prospect Harbor, ME,
March 16, 2010

Front view of the Down East Deli,
March 16, 2010

scopecontent.p: Front view of the Down East Deli. One of the few stores on the main street through the village, even this store was up for sale.

View of the Stinson factory from the other side of Prospect Harbor with fishing boats in the harbor. While there is still some dragging, scalloping, and sea-urchin fishing still going on in the area, it is very minor. Almost all fishing effort involves lobstering this far down east.

did.unittitle:
Beach Cliff Sardine sign at entrance to Stinson's,
March 30, 2010

scopecontent.p: Beach Cliff Sardine sign at entrance to Stinson's. Known as Big Jim, this sign was once used to welcome people to Maine on the highway. Originally made in wood, it was being taken down and Stinson brought it to Prospect Harbor and it became the symbol on the Beech Cliff brand of sardines. The sign was rebuilt in metal. His boots are over five feet tall.

did.unittitle:
Big Jim from the front,
March 1, 2010

Big Jim from the back,
March 30, 2010

scopecontent.p: View of the facility looking from the wharf towards the mouth of the harbor. The wharf is where fresh sardines were landed by boat. Sardine carriers would tie up here and the fish was pumped from their holds. Stinson's eventually took in frozen fish as well by truck to extend their processing schedule. On the left is where overboard discharged was screened out through roto-strainers. The bait area is just a little bit to the right - cuttings and whole bait for lobstermen.

did.unittitle:
View further down on back side of plant - used to be can manufacturing section - turned into the casing operation,
March 30, 2010

scopecontent.p: View further down on back side of plant - used to be can manufacturing section - turned into the casing operation. Cans made in 1960 until around 2003 or '04. The can making machinery was then sent to Blacks Harbor when Connors Brothers took over in 2000 until 2005 - then BumbleBee purchased the factory.

did.unittitle:
Outside of plant - air-handling equipment,
March 30, 2010

One section of a warehouse used to store products and supplies,
March 30, 2010

Back of boiler room. Dumpsters and behind them a 10,000 gallon bunker-C oil tank,
March 30, 2010

scopecontent.p: Back of boiler room. Dumpsters and behind them a 10,000 gallon bunker-C oil tank. Storage buildings to the left. There were two, 200 hp boilers - Superior Boilers for steam. Steam used for processing, heated water for the can washer, the retorts, and to heat the building. Burned 1100 gallons a day in winter. Summer, 400-700 gallons, depending on the production of the day. All steam to the steam boxes was in and out - not recovered. Heaters were recovered and condensate brought back into boiler room. All equipment and chimney removed after plant closed.

did.unittitle:
Three - ten thousand gallon water tanks,
March 30, 2010

scopecontent.p: Three - ten thousand gallon water tanks. Water comes from two artesian wells about a mile away and is stored in those tanks - reserve for production. Fresh water. In 2009 line was run underground and across the harbor to supply factory - very good water.

did.unittitle:
De-watering tower,
March 30, 2010

scopecontent.p: De-watering tower - screen the water out as fish were pumped from carry boats before it went into tank trucks or totes.

did.unittitle:
Crane used to lower suction-hose into fish carrier,
March 30, 2010

scopecontent.p: Crane used to lower suction-hose into fish carrier. Army surplus crane from Massachusetts. Found in junk-yard. Alexander welding made new OSHA approved framework.

did.unittitle:
Side entryway and signs,
March 30, 2010

Floorplan of factory,
March 2010

scopecontent.p: Floorplan of factory - taken from emergency exit plan for building.

did.unittitle:
Early morning view of de-watering tower,
March 29, 2010

Early morning view of de-watering tower and lobster traps on dock next door,
March 29, 2010

First workers coming in for the day - around 5:30 AM,
March 29, 2010

Coats hanging in one of the staff locker rooms,
March 30, 2010

Frozen blocks of herring - 40 or 50 lb. blocks when fresh fish couldn't be had,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: Frozen blocks of herring - 40 or 50 lb. blocks when fresh fish couldn't be had. Last 3 months of production were frozen. Frozen fish made scheduling easier -they knew how long the day would be. The problem was the amount of fish they could thaw and produce each day was less than they could do with fresh fish. Early years they processed fish from the spring to late fall as fish were caught along coast. In 1960's they went into purse-seining, in deeper waters, and that allowed them to get more fish for the winter time, so they started producing in the winter as well. 1980's-90's pair-trawling allowed them to fish in even deeper water and rougher weather. Purse-seining you had a small boat that had to encircle the fish which couldn't be done in rough weather. When the quotas began in the 2000 era, reductions occurred in the amount of fish that could be caught, so they got frozen fish to supplement their catch. Fish were then caught in November and December when the fish were clean and in good shape, and they would freeze the amount they needed for April, May and even into June. That allowed Stinson's to produce year-round. The fish were brought in and frozen on shore. The bulk of the frozen fish came from New Jersey, and some from New Bedford. Stinson's didn't have their own freezers.

did.unittitle:
Frozen blocks of herring,
March 30, 2010

Frozen blocks of herring,
March 29, 2010

Frozen blocks of herring,
March 29, 2010

Frozen blocks of herring,
March 29, 2010

Cardboard boxes from which frozen herring had been removed,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: Cardboard boxes from which frozen herring had been removed. Cardboard was recycled.

did.unittitle:
Pallets of frozen herring moved down to the tank room,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: Pallets of frozen herring moved down to the tank room. Fish would thaw in this area throughout the day until loaded into tanks for thawing over night. This fish would be the next day's production.

did.unittitle:
Tank room,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: Tank room. They would offload anywhere from 40,000-50,000 pounds from a truck or as much as 120,000 -140,000 pounds of fish from a boat. They could hold those fish overnight in refrigerated brine. It was an ammonia system used to cool the brine tank - temperatures maintained below 40 degrees - this would preserve them overnight so the enzymes wouldn't ruin the fish. Each tank on the left side of the photo would hold about 10,000 pounds of fish and there were 11 of those tanks. On the right side they were smaller tanks and would hold about 8000 pounds of fish, and there were eight tanks there.

did.unittitle:
Man flumed the fish out of the tanks and into separators,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: This man flumed the fish out of the tanks and into separators. All the fish had to be separated by size prior to cutting so there was a uniform size going to the cutting machines. The thickness of the fish would determine the length of the fish as well. The fish were sent down a series of parallel rollers spaced at various distances apart from one another. The smallest fish would fall through the rollers first and onto a conveyor belt that would take them away. As the distance between rollers increased, larger fish would fall through to their own conveyor by size. Water sprayed on the fish in these images keeps the fish lubricated and separated from each other to aid the sorting process.

did.unittitle:
PVC piping that brought fresh fish from trucks or boats into the tanks along with water to help fill them,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: PVC piping that brought fresh fish from trucks or boats into the tanks along with water to help fill them. Fish, offloaded from either boats or trucks, would be flumed down to these tanks via these pipes. Trucks would offload onto a conveyor, boats directly into pipework. The "Ts" in the photo could be raised or lowered to fill any particular tank. When the tank was full, the T was raised and the fish went to the next tank. These pipes also added water to fill the tanks more quickly.

did.unittitle:
Three workers unload frozen fish into tanks for thawing. Renaldo Perez on right,
March 29, 2010

Fish thawing in tanks - agitated with air and circulation but kept below 50 degrees,
March 29, 2010

Man on left Humberto Garcia, man on right is probably Jose Rodriguez. They would offload the fish out of the tanks and fill the tank back up with water,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: Man on left Humberto Garcia, man on right is probably Jose Rodriguez. They would offload the fish out of the tanks and fill the tank back up with water like you see in picture 39 with the fish being thawed out. Air would also be introduced into the tank along with the now heated water (about 50 degrees) and circulate it to thaw the fish to the desired temperature. They would go into the tank in the morning and be ready for the next day's work. Each tank would hold about 2400 -3000 pounds of frozen blocks of fish. Forklift lifts blocks of frozen herring up to be loaded into the tanks.

did.unittitle:
Renaldo Perez,
March 29, 2010

Frozen herring in tank,
March 29, 2010

Frozen herring in tank,
March 29, 2010

Conveyors and flumes used to move fish to and from separator,
March 29, 2010

Conveyors and flumes used to move fish to and from separator,
March 29, 2010

Donna Eklund,
March 30, 2010

scopecontent.p: Donna Eklund. She could do just about anything asked to do in the plant. Drive forklifts, offload fish, bring cans in. She packed fish for years, worked in the casing room if needed, helped clean up - anything asked of her.

did.unittitle:
Conveyors taking fish to separator machine,
March 29, 2010

Al West - fish procurement man,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: Al West - fish procurement man. He'd been with the company since about 1984. Bought all of the fish and helped with the total operation, having previously been the evening plant supervisor.

did.unittitle:
Conveyors and flumes used to move fish to and from separator,
March 29, 2010

Separator,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: Separator. If more than two different sizes of fish, the third size fish would go to a different conveyor that would put those fish into three holding tanks, and if those tanks filled with that size fish, they would cut those, allowing them to have at least three sizes of fish. That would make it easier for the cutting machines to cut them, as they need to be pretty uniform in size. Sometimes they'd end up with four different sizes, making it more difficult.

did.unittitle:
Fish on conveyor,
March 29, 2010

Pump that pumps the fish steaks,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: Pump that pumps the fish steaks. Take a 12" fish - the tail section of the fish would be about 3-3.5" long - that would be cut as the sardine portion of the fish and go into a different flume line, and from that 3.5" cut up to the gill, up to three pieces of steaks could be cut (cross sections of the fish and they would go into a tank and be pumped over a squirrel cage that would allow the gut cavity to be removed before it went into a tote, prior to the packing line.

did.unittitle:
Fish in the separator. Conveyors underneath bring them to the cutting machines,
March 29, 2010

Flume. Fluming fish around the plant kept damage to the product at a minimum,
March 30, 2010

Flumes,
March 29, 2010

Separator area,
March 29, 2010

Flumes,
March 29, 2010

Conveyor and flume,
March 29, 2010

Three fish left behind,
March 30, 2010

Conveyors and flumes,
March 29, 2010

Conveyors and flumes,
March 30, 2010

Fish left behind - these will be used as lobster bait as with all fish that doesn't make food grade,
March 29, 2010

Automatic cutting machines on the cutting line,
March 30, 2010

scopecontent.p: Automatic cutting machines on the cutting line. There are six cutting machines - three set for one size and three set for the next size up. They would cut as many as 200-250 fish a minute, cutting both the sardine and the steak at the same time - same set of blades. They'd go from the cutting machine to the fish totes by flume. The cutting machine was invented in the 1970's. Dick Trenholm invented fish-steaks. At first they were hand-cut. The fish was put onto a set of blades and you'd lift a lever up to cut the fish. It was very slow, but it utilized all of the fish. Eventually they added a conveyor belt and a moving set of blades to cut the fish and speed the process. Eventually they added hand-feeders to the machines. That was done when Connors Brothers took over. Back in 1986 they closed the South West Harbor plant and that's when they automated Prospect Harbor. They put in what they call Trio machines that would cut the small fish - 5.5 to 7" fish - it would cut those as just sardines only. They also had bigger machines that would cut the fish entirely into fish steaks. Then they invented these machines that could do both. The old McPhearson machines just cut just steaks. They stopped using scissors in 1987, although they still brought in frozen blocks of sprats to supplement the production that would have to be thawed and cut by hand. They were very small - 8 to ten fish per can - 5.5" to 7" fish, so they were cut by hand, but they still used the automated packing line to pack them. It was costly, but a higher priced product in the end. When Connors Brothers took over in 2000 they did away with the sprats and so it was all automated after that. When cutting all with scissors - 100 to 120 packers on the line for the same production with 20 today on the automated line. The packers were going away anyway - a dying breed. 125 packers could do a 1000 cases in a day. They were able to do 3000 cases in a day with the automated line, assuming no breakdowns and good fish flow. 100 cans per case.

did.unittitle:
Eric Burton on the cutting machine - makes sure the fish go in head first onto the belt and into the knives,
March 29, 2010

Fish steaks in waste basket - will become bait for local lobstermen who come to the factory to purchase it,
March 29, 2010

Cutting machines,
March 30, 2010

Unidentified man operating automatic cutting machine,
March 30, 2010

Wade Robinson on left - maintenance manager - had a staff of seven people under him. Tim Cooper on the right - cutting room supervisor - handled about 12-14 people in the cutting room - made sure the flow of fish through the machines was adequate to keep the packers busy,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: Wade Robinson on left - maintenance manager - had a staff of seven people under him. Tim Cooper on the right - cutting room supervisor - handled about 12-14 people in the cutting room - made sure the flow of fish through the machines was adequate to keep the packers busy. Everything had to be pre-cut for the automated line. He'd come in at 4:30 in the morning and they'd start packing at 6:30. They also occasionally cut on Sunday to create a buffer. He'd work six and sometimes seven days a week.

did.unittitle:
Automatic cutting machines on the cutting line,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: Automatic cutting machines on the cutting line. There are six cutting machines - three set for one size and three set for the next size up. They would cut as many as 200-250 fish a minute, cutting both the sardine and the steak at the same time - same set

scopecontent.p: Fishsteaks in totes, ready to be taken to the packing line. Ice was used to keep fish chilled until packed.

Conveyor from cutting machines dumps fish into totes,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: Conveyor from cutting machines dumps fish into totes. Joe Dumont on left and Donna Eklund on the right. Fish were iced as totes were filled. When totes were filled they were stored, the temperature recorded along with code and lot number, then when needed they were forklifted over to a tote dumper onto a conveyor and flumed over to the packing line.

Fish waste that would go into lobster bait,
March 30, 2010

scopecontent.p: Fish waste that would go into lobster bait. If not suitable for bait it would go a local plant to be turned into fishmeal. The cutting room could cut a few hundred thousand pounds a day during the busy season - about five truckloads. That would produce over 3 thousand cases. If they couldn't all be packed during that day, they were iced and held overnight in the totes. A lot of times they would cut for two hours after they got done packing to build a buffer for the next day, which would allow them to start an hour earlier. The packers could out-pack the cutting machines.

did.unittitle:
Cans coming down onto the packing line from above,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: Cans coming down onto the packing line from above. There were ten lanes, five on each side of the line. There were two packers to a station - ten packers on each side. Packers had everything in front of them - fish and cans flowing continuously by. The noise level in this room was quite high with thousands of aluminum cans banging together, so all workers throughout the factory wore ear-plugs. The packers decided who was going to put which fish in the can. Sometimes the first packer put in two fish and the second packer put one, or they would switch. Some packers would pack every other can. They had their routines. They had to work well with each other as a team - you couldn't put a fast and a slow packer together. Two fast packers or two slow packers would work together. It took three or four years once the automated line came in to get the right combination of packers, as they also had to like working together. If they were arguing, they weren't putting fish in cans and they weren't getting paid. Everything was piece-work. They got paid for every hundred cans that they packed. The price depended on the size of the fish. With three fish in a can, they would get 73 cents. 8 fish to a can they could get up to a $1.26, $1.30 per case. Steaks were the same way $2.46 - $2.60 per case.

did.unittitle:
Cans falling into bossy-cart,
March 29, 2010

Penny Beal inspecting cans before retort operation,
March 29, 2010

Bossy Carts,
March 30, 2010

scopecontent.p: Bossy Carts - bottom of cart could be elevated so cans didn't fall far and dent. Penny Beal could lower floor of cart as they filled. Each cart held 3000 cans. Six carts per retort, or 18,000 cans. The cart was wheeled up to the retort and a cog on a conveyor in the retort would catch the cart and take it off its chassis, keeping the wheels and dirt out of the retort. The old style retorts were vertical - held 1700 gallons of cushion water, and cans would go into them, and they'd lower the water as it filled with cans. They held 18,000 cans as well, but used 1700 gallons of water. When they cooled those retorts, they also used 1000-1500 gallons of water to cool the cans. Additionally, on the bottom of the retort, you had a lot of pressure on the cans with 16000 cans above them. These modern horizontal retorts only have 3000 cans in each cart and only used 150 gallons of water, saving a lot of water per batch. They were using as much as 75-80,000 gallons of water a day, and that was cut down to about 25-30,000 with these new retorts.

did.unittitle:
The 4 retorts,

Retort electronic control equipment,

Water spray in retort,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: Shows water spray in retort. Retort is a pressure cooker that sterilizes the product. Cans are hermetically sealed and still have bacteria in them. Operates at 240 degrees for 50 minutes. With a sauce, 252 degrees at fifty-five minutes. The higher temperatures would discolor the tomato and mustard sauces. Pressure kept the cans from exploding.

scopecontent.p: Trudy Mayer - in charge of the automated packaging machine. In this machine, cans were stacked 12 high on a conveyor belt, long enough to do two rows at a time on a box. So once the cans were stacked 12 high, it would push the 24 cans into a box that was pre- glued and up-righted. The case would then slide down and the top would be glued and stacked on a pallet.

Model of Ida Mae - sardine carrier owned by Stinson's for years,
March 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: Model of Ida Mae - sardine carrier owned by Stinson's for years. At one point she was turned into a mussel dragger. Also used it to carry shrimp one year when they did shrimp. Eventually turned back into a sardine carrier - it is still in operation as of 1/2011. In the 60's-70's the fish were salted. After that, the government required them to be iced - most people preferred the salted, as the quality seemed better. She could carry around 81 hogshead - 1225 lbs. to a hogshead - she was a small carrier.

Subseries 2.
Finest Kind: The Lobstermen of Corea Maine
files,
June 28 2010 through July 30 2010

scopecontent.p: Files, primarily photographs, created during Starr's project. Also included is one inventory spreadsheet containing descriptive data for every photo and a digital copy of Starr's book 'Finest Kind The Lobstermen of Corea Maine.pdf'. In addition to copies of the photographs, the book contains transcribed interviews with a dozen fisherman and their families, extensive information about the lobster fishing trade and industry, and Starr's descriptions of the documentary project.

arrangement.p: The digital files on disk have not been rearranged from their original order. The manuscript files have been described in alphabetical order in the finding aid and the photographs are listed in numerical order by ID number. The photographs' titles and ID numbers are copied from Starr's item level metadata in his descriptive spreadsheet "manifest_ph0337-ph0824_inventory.xls". The descriptions and listings of individuals in the photos are used as titles. If a description was too long to be an effective title archivists shortened it and recorded the original description in the item's Scope and Content note. The dates come from the photographs' EXIF metadata, except where that data is clearly inaccurate. In those cases archivists estimated an accurate date. See the inventory and files' metadata for more context.

did.unittitle:
Photo inventory,
July 2010

Two lobstermen paddle their skiff home past docks stacked with gear in Prospect Harbor,
July 20, 2010

scopecontent.p: Two lobstermen paddle their skiff home past docks stacked with gear in Prospect Harbor. This standing and paddling method used to propel skiffs is the standard in the harbor.

did.unittitle:
Two fiberglass lobsterboats at anchor at end of day,
July 18, 2010

scopecontent.p: Two fiberglass lobsterboats at anchor at end of day. Nearly all boats in the harbor are glass, although there are a few wooden boats left. Boat on left is Arvid Young's boat, of Young's Boatbuilders fame.

did.unittitle:
Boats at rest in front of Corea Fishermen's Coop,
July 20, 2010

scopecontent.p: Boats at rest in front of Corea Fishermen's Coop. All but a few boats in the harbor belong to the coop. Lobstermen get bait, fuel and supplies from the coop and drop off their catch at the end of the day. Hired workers at the coop box and sell the catch for them.

did.unittitle:
Virgo heads up into Gouldsboro Bay,
July 22, 2010

scopecontent.p: Virgo heads up into Gouldsboro Bay. Just above Corea's harbor, this bay is nearly 7 miles deep and nearly all of the Corea fishermen set traps in the bay (note the number of buoys in the photo - the whole bay is covered with them) although most of the fishermen also fish out in the open ocean, depending on the movement of the lobsters. Lobsters travel on or offshore depending on water temperatures. Doubles, primarily, are fished in the bay, along with singles, due to the crowded conditions. Longer trawls, of anywhere from 5 to 30 traps are fished offshore to save time where entanglements are less likely.

did.unittitle:
Gulls sitting on wire traps,
July 20, 2010

scopecontent.p: Gulls sitting on wire traps. Gear encircles Corea harbor in the off season.

did.unittitle:
Two boats heading out of Gouldsboro Bay,
July 22, 2010

Two lobstermen paddle out to the Pamela Ann for a day's work,
July 21, 2010

scopecontent.p: Two lobstermen paddle out to the Pamela Ann for a day's work. The man on the right is the oldest man fishing in Corea - 80 years old at the time of the photo. Brandon Sprague left, Babe Crowley right

did.unittitle:
Two lobstermen paddle home at the end of the day's work. Ethan Whittaker left, Brandon Johnson right,
July 19, 2010

Two lobstermen load bait for the next day's fishing,
July 21, 2010

scopecontent.p: Two lobstermen load bait for the next day's fishing. Herring is the preferred bait in Corea, but alewives are used when they run upstream in local waters in the spring.

did.unittitle:
Lobstermen's wharfs are used to store gear and as a place from which to load their vessels with equipment. They can also tie their vessels to the piers and wait for low tide to inspect the bottoms of their boats or make repairs,
July 19, 2010

scopecontent.p: Lobstermen's wharfs are used to store gear and as a place from which to load their vessels with equipment. They can also tie their vessels to the piers and wait for low tide to inspect the bottoms of their boats or make repairs. The shacks on the dock originally were used in the winters as workshops, where they could make wooden traps and buoys (no longer used anywhere) or maintain other gear. Lobstermen now mostly work on gear in other locations. Note the lobster car in the foreground loaded with spare traps. As not all fishermen have wharfs, sometimes gear is stored on the water. Cars are used to store lobsters until needed for sale - floating crates that can double as docks.

did.unittitle:
Tools of the trade. A lobster gauge on top measures both the short and long legal limits,
July 19, 2010

scopecontent.p: Tools of the trade. A lobster gauge on top measures both the short and long legal limits. At the time of the photos, lobsters had to measure at least 3.25" and no longer than 5." along the carapace. The device on the bottom is a bander - used to stretch the rubber bands around the claws of lobsters they were going to keep - this protected the fishermen from claws while also keeping the lobsters from tearing each other apart. Both tools are made from stainless steel.

did.unittitle:
Virgo in Gouldsboro Bay. Captain is about to launch a trap back into the water,
July 22, 2010

Three vessels await their turn to unload at the Coop,
July 23, 2010

scopecontent.p: Three vessels await their turn to unload at the Coop. The Coop can only handle two boats at a time, so vessels idle in the mouth of the harbor until a spot opens up on the docks. Boats leave from the harbor anywhere from 4AM to 7Am and begin to return in the early afternoon.

did.unittitle:
Boats in the harbor at the end of the day,
July 24, 2010

scopecontent.p: Boats in the harbor at the end of the day. Note the stony nature of the harbor shoreline.

did.unittitle:
Skiffs tied to the dock,
July 18, 2010

scopecontent.p: Skiffs tied to the dock. Many of the skiffs in the harbor are home-made by the fishermen, although there are also commercial skiffs in use. Only one or two have outboards on them - an unnecessary expense and an additional maintenance problem they don't need.

did.unittitle:
More skiffs. Fishermen paddle their skiff out to the boat and leave it on the boat's mooring until they return at the end of the day,
July 24, 2010

Low tide and skiffs,
July 24, 2010

Fish ladder to the pond on the Guzzle Road. In the spring, a trap is set here for alewives that head into the pond to spawn,
July 25, 2010

scopecontent.p: Fish ladder to the pond on the Guzzle Road. In the spring, a trap is set here for alewives that head into the pond to spawn. Fishermen buy the rights to the fish at a town auction each year - promising to pay so much per bushel of fish. This bait is then sold to others in Corea. Ethan Whitaker owned the rights at the time of the photo, and he lives just up the street, as does his father.

scopecontent.p: Trap coming aboard onto the sidedeck. This is the tail trap of a double trawl. It will be slid aft to the sternman and the captain will deal with the head trap that comes aboard next.

scopecontent.p: Boat at the Coop dock unloading lobsters. Kevin on the left weighs lobsters from the boat and will make out a slip with the final number of pounds landed. Bruce Hartford on the boat has another tote of lobsters to land. The traps on the boat were picked up during the day and will be moved to another location ahead of the lobster's migration. did.unittitle:
Brandon Sprague and Babe Crowley head to the next string of traps on the Pamela Ann. Brandon Sprague left, Babe Crowley right,
July 29, 2010

Babe Crowley and Brandon Sprague empty and rebait a pair of traps on the bay. Babe (Harold) Crowley left, Brandon Sprague right,
July 22, 2010

Babe Crowley grabs a buoy with a boothook,
July 22, 2010

scopecontent.p: Babe Crowley grabs a buoy with a boothook. The boat runs up on a buoy so that the captain can grab the buoys and then feed the line through the block and into the pot hauler. Sea urchins line the deck and rails. Unwanted guests, the urchins can fully pack the trap and keep lobsters out. They are sometimes crushed or simply dumped back overboard, and cost much time and effort. There is a winter business in sea urchin harvesting in Corea. Divers collect the urchins and they are sent to Japan for consumption.

scopecontent.p: Babe and Brandon empty traps of lobsters. Lobsters that are obviously too short or long are tossed back overboard. The rest will be placed in the compartments in the table in the foreground to be measured with gauges when time allows. If they are the right size, they will be banded and put into tanks with circulating water.

did.unittitle:
Calypso heads out to Gouldsboro Bay,
July 22, 2010

Calypso heads out to Gouldsboro Bay,
July 22, 2010

Calypso hauling traps outside of Gouldsboro bay,
July 27, 2010

Bait bags ready for use,
July 19, 2010

scopecontent.p: Bait bags ready for use. The sternmen on lobster boats pre-load baitbags to keep things moving once the boat gets to the traps. Traps are hauled, emptied, baited and relaunched within minutes. These bags are filled with herring, although when these photos were taken, fishermen were also using pogies, which they did not like. Getting bait and the cost of bait were a real problem for Corea fishermen in the summer of 2010

did.unittitle:
Bait bags ready for use,
July 19, 2010

scopecontent.p: Bait bags ready for use. The sternmen on lobster boats pre-load baitbags to keep things moving once the boat gets to the traps. Traps are hauled, emptied, baited and relaunched within minutes. These bags are filled with herring, although when these photos were taken, fishermen were also using pogies, which they did not like. Getting bait and the cost of bait were a real problem for Corea fishermen in the summer of 2010

did.unittitle:
Banding lobsters at the table,
July 19, 2010

scopecontent.p: Banding lobsters at the table. Rubber bands are stretched by the plier-like banding tool and protect both the fishermen and other lobsters from the powerful claws.

did.unittitle:
A cormorant fishing in the bay,
July 20, 2010

A "berried" female lobster,
July 19, 2010

scopecontent.p: A "berried" female lobster. Tens of thousands of lobster eggs are glued to the tail of this female. Egg bearing females are thrown back overboard, as they represent the future of fishing. They can also be v-notched. A v-cut notch in the tail marks the bearing female even if she has no eggs, and no lobster with a v-notch can be landed. This has assured a continuing crop of lobsters for Maine fishermen.

did.unittitle:
Low tide,
July 28, 2010

scopecontent.p: Low tide. The tidal range in Corea Harbor keeps fishermen from simply tying their boats to their wharves. Lobster boats are moored on fixed anchors because of this. Note in this mid-day photo that most of the fleet is out working.

did.unittitle:
Low tide,
July 28, 2010

scopecontent.p: Low tide. The tidal range in Corea Harbor keeps fishermen from simply tying their boats to their wharves. Lobster boats are moored on fixed anchors because of this.

did.unittitle:
Leigh Farnsworth unloading her catch at the coop,
July 29, 2010

scopecontent.p: Leigh Farnsworth unloading her catch at the coop. At the time of these photos, she was one of two women captains in the harbor. There were many women working as sternmen (they prefer to be called sternmen rather than sternwomen, fishermen over fisherwoman). Mostly they avoid the semantic gender problem by saying they fish or they stern on a lobster boat. Corea has a long history of women in the industry - wives often helped husbands on their boats in the past. Today, there are many husband/wife teams working from the harbor.

did.unittitle:
Hauling block that leads the line from the trap to the automatic pot-hauler,

scopecontent.p: Hauling block that leads the line from the trap to the automatic pot-hauler. These blocks, from Tenant's Harbor, seem to be the block used throughout the industry in New England.

did.unittitle:
Foam buoys,
June 28, 2010

scopecontent.p: Foam buoys. Many of the elder fishermen talked of the days when they carved their buoys from cedar trees. The wooden buoys would have to be swapped out during the summer as they became waterlogged. Buoys are painted with the official colors assigned to each lobsterman, and one example of their buoy is prominently displayed on their vessel.

scopecontent.p: Christine A hauled and placed next to owner's garage. Corea's fleet is hauled for winter by a hydraulic trailer and the boats are often stored for a few months in the owner's yard. In some cases, when the owner has died, the boat is hauled and brought home in the summer. There are a handful of boats in the harbor that fish all winter and are not hauled at all.

scopecontent.p: Bruce Crowley works to untangle two sets of trawls. Given the crowded condition of the bay, lobstermen occasionally need to disengage their gear from those of another. It seems almost possible to walk across the bay on buoys alone. Despite the feeling that no lobsters could ever leave the bay their own, the yearly catch for lobsters along the Maine coast has risen each year to a new record.

Kevin Scully (center of 3 men) Mike Bragdon bottom of photo.

did.unittitle:
Dan Whitaker hangs a bait bag inside a trap,
July 27, 2010

scopecontent.p: Dan Whitaker hangs a bait bag inside a trap. The bait is stuffed into these bags by the sternman, and the bags are hung in the trap to attract lobsters. Bags were once made of cotton and needed frequent replacing as they rotted fairly quickly. Today they are made of synthetic fibers and last a long time. Dan Whitaker - first generation lobsterman.

scopecontent.p: Dan Whitaker at the helm. He is a first generation fisherman - both of his sons fish from the harbor as well.

did.unittitle:
Dana Tracy,
July 23, 2010

Dana Tracy heads to his boat the Daily Bread,
June 30, 2010

Dan Whitaker and Bruce Hartford working traps offshore. Dan Whitaker right, Bruce Hartford left,
July 27, 2010

Dan Whitaker at the helm,
July 27, 2010

Dan Whitaker attaching whale-rope to a set of traps,
July 24, 2010

scopecontent.p: Dan Whitaker attaching whale-rope to a set of traps. Whale-rope is a weighted rope that sinks to the ocean floor - an attempt to keep whales from becoming entangled in the warps. It is now mandatory out beyond an imaginary line set by the government along the coast. Besides the added expense, the lines now chafe along the rocky bottom and fishermen lose their traps, causing many of them to give up their offshore sites.

Fish ladder to the pond on the Guzzle Road,
July 25, 2010

scopecontent.p: Fish ladder to the pond on the Guzzle Road. In the spring, a trap is set here for alewives that head into the pond to spawn. Fishermen buy the rights to the fish at a town auction each year - promising to pay so much per bushel of fish. This bait is then sold to interested parties. This makes for a cheaper bait - a major expense for lobstermen at this time in history.

scopecontent.p: The Fundy Wanderer heads to sea for a day's work. This type of boat is known as a Novie Boat - the high bow is typical of the boats built in Nova Scotia to handle open seas. This high bow, while helpful in heavy seas, makes it hard to see trap buoys in calm waters like those fished near Corea.

did.unittitle:
An automatic pot hauler,
July 19, 2010

scopecontent.p: An automatic pot hauler. Hydraulically operated, two spinning disks form a "V" into which the pot warp is placed to haul the traps. This revolutionized the industry, and allowed fishermen to haul the newer wire traps which have no natural buoyance like the wooden traps did. It also allowed the fishermen to work in deep waters and haul multiple traps at once, saving their backs much effort.

July 26, 2010

Wharf on right and railway for hauling lobster cars on left,
July 20, 2010

scopecontent.p: Wharf on right and railway for hauling lobster cars on left. While there are no railways that can haul boats in the harbor (all boats are hauled with a hydraulic trailer from a launch ramp) there are the remains of several small railways used to haul lobster cars - the floating boxes lobstermen use to store live lobsters in. Free flow of water through the crates keep the lobsters alive until sold. Cars also double as docks in the harbor.

Early photograph of fishermen in Corea Harbor purse seining bait,
July 27, 2010

scopecontent.p: Early photograph of fishermen in Corea Harbor purse seining bait. When schools of herring come into the small harbors, fishermen took advantage and netted them for bait from these small boats. They would also "torch" them at night - use a torch light to attract the fish and then scoop them up with dip nets. Photograph is from an family album owned by Mrs. Morna Briggs. Her husband was a lobsterman as is one of her sons. She also lobstered with her husband as he got older. Photo of a photo.

Series 2. 2015 accrual:
Against the Tide
,
Down On The Farm
,
In History's Wake
, and
Voices From The Waterfront
photographs,
March 26, 2005 through December 4, 2013

scopecontent.p:
Accrual is 841 images, 4 corresponding spreadsheets, 4 book pdfs, and 1 moving image. All the files except the moving image concern four of Starr's documentary projects:
Against the Tide: The Commercial Fishermen of Point Judith RI
,
Down On The Farm: The Last Dairy Farms of North Stonington
,
In History's Wake: The Last Trap Fishermen of RI
, and
Voices From The Waterfront: Portrait of the New Bedford Fishing Industry
. The photos generally depict subjects at work, tools and implements, and worksites. Every photo has an item level description, which are saved with the photos in four spreadsheets - see this series' Arrangement note for more information. In addition to copies of the photographs, the book PDFs all contain descriptions of Starr's (and, in the case of
Voices from the Waterfront
, his collaborators') motivations and historical information about the documented trade and industry. All the PDFs but
Against the Tide
also contain edited and excerpted transcriptions of interviews with documentary subjects. The moving image is the independent film
Scalloping on the Mister G
. It is Starr's 2011 documentary narrated by Capt. Mike Marchetti, which records a day in the life of three fishermen who day-scallop from the port of Point Judith, RI.

arrangement.p: This accrual continues the image numbering from where DC_01 (the previous series) ended, but the filenames have not had "afc2013031_ph" prepended. The filenames for "Against the Tide" follow a different pattern than the others - the first four digits are the unique ID and the following digits are the date the photograph was taken. The donor's spreadsheets use unique IDs to associate his descriptions with the files. The files are in four folders - each of the folders are named after the project for which the images were created.

processinfo.p:
Charles Hosale added the PDF files to the series in November 2020. The PDFs had previously been stored separately.
Scalloping on the Mister G
was originally delivered to the archive on a DVD in 2015. In 2021 Starr delivered a new born-digital copy from his personal files. The file in this collection is the 2021 copy.

did.unittitle:
Scalloping on the Mister G
,
2011

Subseries 1.
Against the Tide: The Commercial Fishermen of Point Judith RI
files,
March 26, 2005 through December 2, 2013

scopecontent.p:
Files, primarily photographs, created during Starr's project. Also included is one inventory spreadsheet containing descriptive data for every photo and a digital copy of Starr's book
Against the Tide: The Commercial Fishermen of Point Judith RI
.

arrangement.p: The digital files on disk have not been rearranged from their original order. The manuscript files have been described in alphabetical order in the finding aid and the photographs are listed in numerical order by ID number. The photographs' titles and ID numbers are copied from Starr's item level metadata in his descriptive spreadsheet "Against the Tide The Commercial Fishermen of Point Judith RI.xls". The descriptions and listings of individuals in the photos are used as titles. If a description was too long to be an effective title archivists shortened it and recorded the original description in the item's Scope and Content note. The dates also come from the inventory metadata. See the inventory and files' metadata for more context.

did.unittitle:
Fisherman as Grim Reaper,
November 2, 2007

Seamus & Liam heads out carrying new traps for deployment,
June 11, 2007

scopecontent.p: Seamus & Liam heads out carrying new traps for deployment. Fishermen often bring traps back to port on each trip that require work or cleaning. When traps become covered in growth they are heavier and less efficient. They are usually steam cleaned and returned to work. This is a day boat - lobstering near shore only, whereas Pt. Judith has many offshore lobsterboats as well.

did.unittitle:
Rubber chafing gear used on the bottom of a scallop dredge,
May 9, 2007

scopecontent.p: Rubber chafing gear used on the bottom of a scallop dredge. Punched from old tires, most rubber chafing gear comes from F&B Rubberized in New Bedford, MA., and is used to reduce wear on more expensive components of fishing gear.

did.unittitle:
Bait barrels for lobstermen are covered to keep seagulls from pilfering,
September 14, 2007

scopecontent.p: Bait barrels for lobstermen are covered to keep seagulls from pilfering. Miss Judith tied to the dock during an inactive period - note her nets are covered on the stern reel. Most of Pt. Judith trawlers were made of steel at this point in time, although there were a few dozen wooden vessels still working at this time - smaller inshore day boats. By 2013, almost all of the wooden boats had disappeared.

did.unittitle:
View of large trawler docks looking up the harbor,
February 8, 2007

scopecontent.p: View of large trawler docks looking up the harbor. The building to the right is a buying station.

did.unittitle:
Anthony Richards prepares to dump the scallop dredge aboard the Njord,
October 23, 2007

scopecontent.p: Anthony Richards prepares to dump the scallop dredge aboard the Njord. The dredge has been brought aboard and the winch tackle shifted to allow the dredge to dump its load on deck. This trip was outside of Long Island, and ended after a few days due to severe weather. When too rough, the dredge bounces ineffectively along the bottom.

did.unittitle:
Lobster boat Trudy S fishing in a heavy fog,
October 24, 2007

scopecontent.p: Lobster boat Trudy S fishing in a heavy fog. Modern radar and GPS units allow fishermen to find their traps and watch for hazards while fishing, giving them more days at sea.

did.unittitle:
Trawler Heritage, owned by the William's family, heads out the breach way on a five trip to Georges Bank,
December 2, 2013

scopecontent.p: Trawler Heritage, owned by the William's family, heads out the breach way on a five trip to Georges Bank. The family also owns Tradition, and Independence.

did.unittitle:
Ellen Schomer and Kevin Tuttle sort fish on Rebecca Mary on a day trip groundfishing in Block Island Sound,
October 18, 2007

scopecontent.p: Ellen Schomer and Kevin Tuttle sort fish on Rebecca Mary on a day trip groundfishing in Block Island Sound. The trip was cut short after tearing their net - the tear too big to repair at sea. This was one of Ellen's last trips after 30 years at sea. At this time, she and one other woman were the only women fishing steadily from the port. Nearly all trawlers were equipped with a conveyor system used to sort fish at this time - saving many backs and knees.

did.unittitle:
Gear on the back deck of Njord, a steel scalloping boat owned by Peter Nicholson,
October 23, 2007

Roland Smith or "Bucky" sits against the pilothouse of the Amelia Bucolo as they steam to their trap,
January 28, 2008

scopecontent.p: Roland Smith or "Bucky" sits against the pilothouse of the Amelia Bucolo as they steam to their trap. Bucky began fishing at age ten and fished offshore for most of his career. He now works as a welder in the winter months and trap fishes in the summer.

did.unittitle:
Allan Glidden sorts fish on the deck of the Amelia Bucolo as Jim Main tends the ship's winch,
January 28, 2008

scopecontent.p: Allan Glidden sorts fish on the deck of the Amelia Bucolo as Jim Main tends the ship's winch. Trap fishing is a day fishery with a long history. Traps had been set on the Rhode Island coast for hundreds of years, although when this photo was taken, only four companies remained of the hundreds that once worked the coastline.

did.unittitle:
Perseverance at the dock on a foggy day,
January 28, 2008

scopecontent.p: Perseverance at the dock on a foggy day. Much of the fleet was docked due to very heavy weather.

did.unittitle:
The Amelia Bucolo heads out on a foggy morning to her trap site at Black Rock, just east of Point Jude,
January 28, 2008

scopecontent.p: The Amelia Bucolo heads out on a foggy morning to her trap site at Black Rock, just east of Point Jude. She is piloted by her captain Jim Main, a career fisherman. The Bucolo was specifically built as a carry boat for the trap industry by the Mendonza family, once the biggest trapping firm in RI.

did.unittitle:
Capt. Bligh returns from an offshore crabbing trip under stormy skies,
December 21, 2006

scopecontent.p: Capt. Bligh returns from an offshore crabbing trip under stormy skies. This vessel usually lobsters, but when crabs are plentiful she will take advantage of them as well.

did.unittitle:
Dennis Dimon sorting fish on Vic Ter Rae on a squid fishing trip to Georges Bank,

scopecontent.p: Dennis Dimon sorting fish on Vic Ter Rae on a squid fishing trip to Georges Bank. Denis often fishes with his brother Lewis Dimon IV and nephew Lewis Dimon V. Denis lost the use of one eye in a fishing accident.

did.unittitle:
Fishing alone, R.G. Billings works near the RI coastline on the David D,
January 28, 2008

scopecontent.p: Fishing alone, R.G. Billings works near the RI coastline on the David D. The David D is typical of the earlier, small, wooden draggers once found along the New England coastline. Fished generally as day or short trip boats, these vessels were largely replaced by steel hulled offshore boats once the 200 mile limit was made into law. R.G. Billings

Kate & Sean returning to Pt. Jude at the end of a day trip groundfishing in Block Island Sound,

did.unittitle:
Charlie's Pride on Georges Bank at sunset, trawling for squid,
January 28, 2008

scopecontent.p: Charlie's Pride on Georges Bank at sunset, trawling for squid. Trips to the banks for vessels that carried ice or used refrigerated tanks were usually five day trips, while the few freezer boats in the Pt. Jude fleet could stay at sea for 10 days. Georges Bank is a 24 hour steam from Pt. Jude.

did.unittitle:
Bow art on Jessie James,
January 2, 2007

scopecontent.p: Bow art on Jessie James. A painter at Pro-Met Shipyard in Providence, RI, prided himself on his bow art paintings, and at one point in time, many of the vessels in the fleet sported his work. As times got tougher, these whimsical paintings disappeared.

did.unittitle:
Jerry Babcock and Rodman Sykes sorting the catch on the Deborah Lee,
August 23, 2007

scopecontent.p: Jerry Babcock and Rodman Sykes sorting the catch on the Deborah Lee. This trip was to catch skate to be used as lobster bait. The bait was sold to The Bait Company on the Pt. Jude waterfront, who in turn sold it to local lobstermen. Jerry Babcock and Rodman Sykes (left to right).

did.unittitle:
Stacy Dziekan prepares to hook onto the steel doors aboard the Mikhela Louise on an offshore trip for squid as the net, just hauled aboard, soaks the deck,
October 22, 2007

scopecontent.p: Stacy Dziekan prepares to hook onto the steel doors aboard the Mikhela Louise on an offshore trip for squid as the net, just hauled aboard, soaks the deck. Fishing on offshore trips takes place around the clock, with the net hauled back about every three hours. Once the fish have been dumped, the net is reset and the vessel continues trawling while crew sort the catch. Once the deck is cleared, fishermen head to their bunks to sleep until the net is once again hauled. If in the fish, crew may not get a chance to leave the deck at all.

did.unittitle:
Ice encrusts the gear on the Miss Trudy,
February 28, 2007

scopecontent.p: Ice encrusts the gear on the Miss Trudy. Fishing was not limited by weather or season, making it a dangerous profession.

did.unittitle:
The Amelia Bucolo on a foggy morning at her trap site at Black Rock, just east of Point Jude,
October 31, 2007

scopecontent.p: The Amelia Bucolo on a foggy morning at her trap site at Black Rock, just east of Point Jude. She is piloted by her captain Jim Main, a career fisherman. The Bucolo was specifically built as a carry boat for the trap industry by the Mendonza family. Here, she waits for the longboats to get into position on the trap before she ties up to the head end of the "kitchen" portion of the trap.

did.unittitle:
Stacy Dziekan sorting fish on the Mikhela Louise on an offshore trip for squid,

scopecontent.p: Stacy Dziekan sorting fish on the Mikhela Louise on an offshore trip for squid. Stacy also served as cook aboard the vessel. In Pt. Judes' peak, trawlers carried a separate man as cook and large crews, but by this time crew had shrunk to the minimum size necessary and each crew member performed several jobs.

did.unittitle:
A deckload of cod and flounder aboard Tradition outside of Block Island,
March 15, 2007

Bait barrels for lobstermen are covered to keep seagulls from pilfering,
April 2, 2007

scopecontent.p: Bait barrels for lobstermen are covered to keep seagulls from pilfering. Plastic barrels replaced wooden ones long ago. The smells in summer along the lobster boat docks can be rather pungent. Tourists believe rotten bait is best, but fishermen actually prefer the freshest bait they can get as it will last longer in their traps. Pt. Jude lobstermen primarily use herring, skate, and pogies, but any other fish will do in a pinch.

did.unittitle:
Charlie Brayton aboard his vessel Kelsi & Morgan catching skate for The Bait Company in Point Jude,
July 11, 2007

scopecontent.p: Charlie Brayton aboard his vessel Kelsi & Morgan catching skate for The Bait Company in Point Jude. The vessel's auto pilot takes over once fish are landed on deck, allowing the captain to sort fish as well. Frequent checks of the radar assure safety during the captain's absence from the wheelhouse. The vessel is named after two of Charlie's grandchildren.

did.unittitle:
Pogies,
April 30, 2007

scopecontent.p: Pogies. These fish, while collected by larger vessels for their Omega III oils, are most often used as lobster bait in Pt. Jude.

did.unittitle:
The smaller, fiberglass trawler Slacker returns after a day of ground fishing in Block Island Sound,
January 6, 2007

scopecontent.p: The smaller, fiberglass trawler Slacker returns after a day of ground fishing in Block Island Sound. Fiberglass is only useful up to a certain size vessel in trawling, so few fiberglass trawlers exist in the fleet. Their initial cost and maintenance costs are relatively low when compared to steel. Most of the lobster fleet is made of fiberglass.

The vessel's auto pilot takes over once fish are landed on deck, allowing the captain to sort fish as well. Frequent checks of the radar assure safety during the captain's absence from the wheelhouse. The vessel is named after two of Charlie's grandchildren.

did.unittitle:
Old School returning to port,
March 23, 2007

scopecontent.p: Old School returning to port. One of the few wooden lobster boats still working, she is termed a "Novi" boat, having been built in Nova Scotia. These boats are known for their high bows, something that helps in northern seas with large waves, but hinders lobstermen somewhat down here due to a decrease in vision as lobstermen approach a particular lobster buoy.

Andrea Incollingo's boots are ready to step into when needed,

Jerry Babcock moving plastic totes on the Deborah Lee,

scopecontent.p: Jerry Babcock moving plastic totes on the Deborah Lee. This trip was to catch skate to be used as lobster bait. The bait was sold to The Bait Company on the Pt. Jude waterfront, who in turn sold it to local lobstermen. Jerry and Rodman Sykes, the owner and captain, have fished together for more than 25 years - very unusual on any vessel.

Brad Stanton (left) and Roland "Bucky" Smith tie the Amelia Bucolo to the head end of the Black Rock Point trap as others prepare to haul the trap in the background,

Isabella Rose unloading her day's catch,
February 23, 2007

scopecontent.p: Isabella Rose unloading her day's catch. Conveyors bring the catch from the deck to the processing plant at the end of the dock. Wire mesh keeps gulls from stealing fish.

did.unittitle:
Mermaid painting on the bow of the Suzanne Beth,
April 2, 2007

scopecontent.p: Mermaid painting on the bow of the Suzanne Beth. Most vessels, during the hey-day of fishing out of Point Jude, had bow art, but given the economic conditions by this time most had been painted over. There was one man at Pro-Met shipyard in Providence who prided himself on creating this artwork. This artwork disappeared when the vessel was sold, the new owner thinking it highly inappropriate. This vessel was a hybrid design - built like an Eastern rig with the high bow and working deck in the center of the vessel, but with a stern reel aft. After hauling, the full net was dragged forward to the center of the vessel for sorting - an attempt to keep the fishermen protected from heavy weather. Unfortunately, on the first voyage, a young crewmember was accidentally wound up in the net and killed, and fishermen never really liked the vessel after that. As an experiment, it never really seemed to work. She was later sold to New Bedford and converted to scalloping.

did.unittitle:
Ellen Schomer on the Rebecca Mary on a day trip groundfishing in Block Island Sound,
January 13, 2007

scopecontent.p: Ellen Schomer on the Rebecca Mary on a day trip groundfishing in Block Island Sound. The trip was cut short after tearing their net - the tear too big to repair at sea. This was one of Ellen's last trips after 30 years at sea. Only a few women fished commercially out of the Point at this time.

did.unittitle:
Mike Marchetti brings a lobster trap aboard the Captain Robert,
May 2, 2007

scopecontent.p: Mike Marchetti brings a lobster trap aboard the Captain Robert. Mike owns the Mister G as well, with which he trawls or scallops, among other things. Mike does whatever he can to make money fishing - including pot fishing, raising mussels, clamming, long lining, quahogging, scalloping, lobstering, and trawling. He even owned a fish trap at one point in time.

did.unittitle:
The Suzanne Beth,
April 5, 2007

scopecontent.p: The Suzanne Beth. This vessel was a hybrid design - built like an Eastern rig with the high bow and working deck in the center of the vessel, but with a stern reel aft. After hauling, the full net was dragged forward to the center of the vessel for sorting - an attempt to keep the fishermen protected from heavy weather. Unfortunately, on the first voyage, a young crewman was accidentally wound up in the net and killed, and fishermen never really liked the vessel after that. As an experiment in new vessel design, it never really seemed to work. She was later sold to New Bedford and converted to scalloping.

did.unittitle:
Lobsters for sale sign on the lobster dock,
August 7, 2007

scopecontent.p: Lobsters for sale sign on the lobster dock. Fishermen could sell lobsters directly to the public as they were still alive. No dead fish can be sold directly to the public, but must pass through the hands of a licensed dealer. Lobstermen could keep more of the profit by selling directly, although most of their catch is still sold to dealers. Lobstermen make their own signs.

Ocean State returns in the fog after a day trip groundfishing off of Block Island,

A trawl cable passes through a block before diving into the ocean while towing in Block Island Sound,
June 11, 2007

scopecontent.p: A trawl cable passes through a block before diving into the ocean while towing in Block Island Sound. The David D, a small wooden trawler, approaches in the background. Note the cloth marker on the steel cable that tells fishermen how much cable has been let out, and thus the angle of the tow given the depth of the water fished.

did.unittitle:
Mike Hopkins slides the pen boards in across the stern ramp opening aboard the Rebecca Mary on a day trip groundfishing in Block Island Sound,
October 18, 2007

scopecontent.p: Mike Hopkins slides the pen boards in across the stern ramp opening aboard the Rebecca Mary on a day trip groundfishing in Block Island Sound. Once the net is hauled onto the deck, pen boards block off the ramp so fish can be dumped without fear of them going back overboard. This also makes is safer for crew as the work the pile.

Lucy M rests at the lobster docks on a foggy day,

scopecontent.p: Lucy M rests at the lobster docks on a foggy day. At this time she was one of the oldest vessel in port, but was seldom fished as her owner had aged as well.

did.unittitle:
The cod end of the net pops to the surface full of fish as it approaches the trawler,
February 28, 2007

scopecontent.p: The cod end of the net pops to the surface full of fish as it approaches the trawler. Note the gulls are already trying to steal a free lunch. Fishermen talked of the days when they could walk out on the nets as they were so full of fish.

did.unittitle:
Two fishermen watch as the net comes aboard the Mikhaela Louise on a squid trip to Georges Bank in very heavy weather,
October 1, 2006

scopecontent.p: Two fishermen watch as the net comes aboard the Mikhaela Louise on a squid trip to Georges Bank in very heavy weather. This first haul-back took more than 40 minutes to land given the weather and the fact it was so packed with fish. Normally, it takes a few minutes to bring the cod end on deck.

She was built for and owned by Chris Brown, and was cut up about 5 years after this photo was taken. Another wooden trawler, the Mabel Susan, is docked to the left.

did.unittitle:
Perseverance at the dock on a foggy day,
January 6, 2007

scopecontent.p: Perseverance at the dock on a foggy day. Much of the fleet was docked due to very heavy weather.

did.unittitle:
A pilot whale breaks the surface on Georges Bank,
February 27, 2007

scopecontent.p: A pilot whale breaks the surface on Georges Bank. These whale listen for the sound of trawlers starting to haul back and then swim over to enjoy a feast. They often swim between the vessel and the net coming towards the ship, but never get caught up in the gear. Once fishermen start sorting, fish to be discarded go back overboard down a chute, and these whales simply follow the vessel eating everything that comes off. Once sorting is done, they disappear, only to be seen again at the next haul back.

scopecontent.p: Pogies. These fish, while collected by larger vessels for their Omega III oils, are most often used as lobster bait in Pt. Jude.

did.unittitle:
Mike Marchetti empties a lobster trap aboard the Captain Robert,
May 2, 2007

scopecontent.p: Mike Marchetti empties a lobster trap aboard the Captain Robert. Mike owns the Mister G as well, with which he trawls or scallops, among other things. Mike does whatever he can to make money fishing - including pot fishing, raising mussels, clamming, long lining, lobstering, trawling and others. On this trip, 90 percent of all lobsters caught went back into the ocean, due to size, v-notching (a v-notch is cut out of a bearing female tail to signal it can't be landed because it is a productive animal) or for being "berried" or carrying eggs.

scopecontent.p: The dragger Cody hauled out for cleaning, painting and repairs across the pond. This small shipyard once serviced most of the fleet - all except the largest steel draggers, but was closed not long after this photo was taken due to new environmental regulations, further adding to the cost and stress of doing business as a fisherman. Vessels now had to travel to larger yards further away, yards that didn't allow fishermen to work on their own vessels.

did.unittitle:
The trawler Barbara Ann as seen through a net that has been unwound from the reel for repair,

Luann leads the parade of fishing vessels during the traditional Blessing of the Fleet,
July 28, 2007

scopecontent.p: Luann leads the parade of fishing vessels during the traditional Blessing of the Fleet. After being blessed by a Cardinal, the lead vessel lays a wreath on the water in remembrance of fellow fishermen lost at sea. Once a huge affair in the port, like everything else in the fishery, this ceremony is now a shadow of what it had been. A wild and raucous celebration in the past, the insurance industry decided the boats wouldn't be covered for the event, so now only a handful of commercial boats participate.

While used in fish & chips in England, the processing of dogfish is elaborate as they urinate through their skin and must be carefully handled to achieve food-grade fish.

did.unittitle:
Loud mouthed local gull,
March 26, 2005

A grey day on Georges Bank,
March 2, 2007

Jake Everich hauling one of Tom Hoxsie's traps form a skiff,
August 20, 2007

Net reel covered on a trawler crossing an area closed to fishing,
March 2, 2007

scopecontent.p: Net reel covered on a trawler crossing an area closed to fishing. Regulations once forced trawlers to steam all the way around closed areas, but due to cost and time involved, the government eventually allowed trawlers to cover their twine and maintain a high speed while crossing these areas instead. On this trip, heavy wind began to tear the cover off. When fishermen stopped to fix the problem, the vessel was immediately contacted by the government to see what they were doing in a restricted area, as all commercial vessels are tracked 24/7 by the government. Fishermen joke there are more people in government watching fishermen than there are fishermen - something that may be true...

Suzanne Beth at the dock,
July 31, 2007

scopecontent.p: Suzanne Beth at the dock. This vessel was a hybrid design - built like an Eastern rig with the high bow and working deck in the center of the vessel, but with a stern reel aft. After hauling, the full net was dragged forward to the center of the vessel for sorting - an attempt to keep the fishermen protected from heavy weather. Unfortunately, on the first voyage, a young crewmember was accidentally wound up in the net and killed, and fishermen never really liked the vessel after that. As an experiment, it never really seemed to work. She was later sold to New Bedford and converted to scalloping.

did.unittitle:
A pilot whale breaks the surface on Georges Bank,
February 28, 2007

scopecontent.p: A pilot whale breaks the surface on Georges Bank. These whale listen for the sound of trawlers starting to haul back and then swim over to enjoy a feast. They often swim between the vessel and the net coming towards the ship, but never get caught up in the gear. Once fishermen start sorting, fish to be discarded go back overboard down a chute, and these whales simply follow the vessel eating everything that comes off. Once sorting is done, they disappear, only to be seen again at the next haul back.

scopecontent.p: Ellen Schomer and Mike Hopkins direct the net as it comes aboard on the Rebecca Mary during a day trip groundfishing in Block Island Sound. The trip was cut short after tearing their net - the tear too big to repair at sea. This was one of Ellen's last trips after 30 years at sea.

Mike Marchetti after hooking onto a lobster pot buoy,

scopecontent.p: Mike Marchetti after hooking onto a lobster pot buoy. The warp to the set of traps is put into the pot hauler which will bring the traps rapidly to the surface. The pot hauler revolutionized the industry, allowing fishermen to bring more traps on the same warp to the ocean surface from deeper waters with less effort.

Bow pulpit,

scopecontent.p: Bow pulpit. Swordfishing was once an important fishery in Pt. Jude, but as with everything else, as technology improved, fishermen were able to overfish the species. Fish were harpooned from these pulpits at one point, but by this time there was no swordfishery left from the Point.

did.unittitle:
Margaret Holly hauling back her net on Georges Bank,

Roller gear stretched out on the dock,
February 21, 2007

scopecontent.p: Roller gear stretched out on the dock. The rubber "cookies" and rollers are punched from used tires by a company in New Bedford. These allow the cables to roll over obstructions on the ocean's bottom and come in all sizes, depending on the terrain fishermen know they will fish.

did.unittitle:
Mike Marchetti cutting scallops aboard the Mister G on a trip out past Block Island,

scopecontent.p: Mike Marchetti cutting scallops aboard the Mister G on a trip out past Block Island. Mike, who considered himself a slow cutter, could cut a scallop in less than six seconds.

Corey T, an offshore lobster boat, heads to sea,

Three men repairing the net aboard the Atlantic Queen,

scopecontent.p: Three men repairing the net aboard the Atlantic Queen. Man in center is owner Follett.

did.unittitle:
Amelia Bucolo steams back to the docks after tending her trap,
September 21, 2006

View of the docks looking north in Point Judith,
August 7, 2007

Saint Jude at her dock,
April 5, 2007

Iced up trawler,
February 8, 2007

scopecontent.p: Iced up trawler. Icing on trawlers can be a deadly condition. When returning home from the warmer waters out on Georges Bank, in blowing winds and cold temperatures, the superstructures on fishing vessels can begin to ice over, and if not knocked off by fishermen can begin to destabilize the ship, causing it to turn turtle. Many crews have been lost when not able to keep up with the icing high above or on the outriggers.

did.unittitle:
The Debbie Ann as a rusted hulk,
