A graduate of Maine Maritime, he chose to fish rather than pursue a career on other types of commercial vessels. Luke also owns and operates the Shirley Ann, a day boat he fishes from the Point when done with the day's trapping.

did.unittitle:
Totes of newly-landed fish, separated by species, await boxing,
October 15, 2008

scopecontent.p: Totes of newly-landed fish, separated by species, await boxing. Few Americans will purchase a whole fish such as these anymore. Once docks brimmed with people waiting to pick the fish they would eat for dinner, but consumers are now far more likely to pull a box from the local grocer's freezer. Today, less than 10 percent of the fish we consume in this country comes from local waters.

did.unittitle:
Crewmembers weigh fish with this hanging scale before placing them in shipping cartons,
April 27, 2008

scopecontent.p: Crewmembers weigh fish with this hanging scale before placing them in shipping cartons. Seemingly old and tired, this scale, like all commercial scales, is calibrated periodically by governmental inspectors. The tangible sense of history and tradition etched into the chipped paint on its ancient face adds a certain elegance missing from its modern digital counterparts.

did.unittitle:
Deckhands chat as they head towards the day's work aboard the Maria Mendonsa,
June 6, 2008

scopecontent.p: Deckhands chat as they head towards the day's work aboard the Maria Mendonsa. While most of a trap crew's time is spent fishing, they must also attend to other tasks throughout the summer season. On this day, crewmembers will remove twine from the trap near the Sakonnet Point Lighthouse. Two in middle left to right: Dan MacDonald, Aaron Taylor.

did.unittitle:
Alan Wheeler gets ready to hook onto netting they will remove through the course of the day's work,
June 6, 2008

scopecontent.p: Alan Wheeler gets ready to hook onto netting they will remove through the course of the day's work. This day, like those on which they deploy traps in the spring, is another in which the entire crew must pay close attention to dangers surrounding them. Adam Lotz left, Alan Wheeler right.

did.unittitle:
It will be a long and gloomy day of rain as the crew removes twine, although this hardly affects their spirits,
June 6, 2008

scopecontent.p: It will be a long and gloomy day of rain as the crew removes twine, although this hardly affects their spirits. Wearing a uniform of foul weather gear even on sunny days, they hardly notice the additional water falling from above.

did.unittitle:
Squid on deck,
May 22, 2008

scopecontent.p: Squid on deck. These cephalopods have enormous eyes, the giant squid having the largest of any animal alive. Propelled by jets of water, they capture their prey within their eight arms and twin tentacles before tearing them apart with a sharp, beak-like mouth. Not only can squid blend into their surrounds by varying the color and patterning on their skin, they also generate clouds of black ink to help them elude predators.

did.unittitle:
Fishermen remove twine from the frame,
June 6, 2008

scopecontent.p: Fishermen remove twine from the frame. Hauling the net vertically using the ship's winch, crewmen pin it to the rail while the portion above is lowered to the deck, allowing another bight of netting to be raised from the sea. As the twine is brought aboard, the cast weights that held the lower edge of the net to the ocean floor are removed. Early on, fishermen used stones to keep twine in place, although these were quickly replaced as weights cast in metal became cheaper. While iron became the standard, even lead was used when economical. Today, when older weights are lost, substitutions are made with ready-made objects such as links from navy anchor chain. Cast concrete weights are occasionally used, but they "float" more than their denser counterparts and are relegated to sections near rocky beaches where they are more likely to be lost.

did.unittitle:
The marine growth fouling this net is obvious, as is the rather wet nature of the day's work,
June 6, 2008

scopecontent.p: The marine growth fouling this net is obvious, as is the rather wet nature of the day's work. It will take the crew several hours to bring aboard all of the trap's twine. In skiff left to right: Sammy Peters, Dan MacDonald.

did.unittitle:
The crew from the North Star loads a leader net into a skiff on yet another dreary day,
June 4, 2008

scopecontent.p: The crew from the North Star loads a leader net into a skiff on yet another dreary day. Twine is usually pulled for inspection and cleaning during lulls in the fishing or if threatened by hurricanes. Ian and Sam pull spider crabs from the mesh as they go, a job far more tedious than one might imagine. Sam Willis left, Ian Campbell right.

did.unittitle:
Tom Hoxsie secures the leader line as Sam and Ian work to reattach the twine,
June 4, 2008

scopecontent.p: Tom Hoxsie secures the leader line as Sam and Ian work to reattach the twine. Tom's traps have provided meals of fresh seafood, bait for other fishermen, and live fish for aquariums around the country. Additionally, a local artist gathers subjects for his Japanese fish prints from Tom's traps because each specimen is undamaged when caught this way.

did.unittitle:
Adam Lotz overlooks the crew as they latch onto the twine,
April 9, 2008

scopecontent.p: Adam Lotz overlooks the crew as they latch onto the twine. Adam, a partner in the company, is responsible for the marketing end of the business as well. Beyond their skills as fishermen, a detailed knowledge of when and where to sell their catch is required to assure financial success. The company's product may travel the Eastern Seaboard, and Adam decides when and where it will go.

did.unittitle:
Sam Willis works to reattach the leader's twine to the Breakwater Village trap at the east end of the harbor,
June 4, 2008

scopecontent.p: Sam Willis works to reattach the leader's twine to the Breakwater Village trap at the east end of the harbor. While Tom's traps may be the smallest, this image provides a feeling for just how big they are still. The skiff is only two-thirds the distance to the shore end of the leader. Tom hires Joe Whaley, a retired local fisherman, to do much of the repair work on his nets, although many of his own hours are spent at this task off-season. The twine itself represents a significant expense, not only for the inherent material costs, but for the labor involved when constructing a trap. Anthony Parascandolo estimated building a full-sized trap from scratch would now take two men nearly six months, working six days a week at that.

did.unittitle:
A longboat from the Christine Roberta stops to repair a cut leader,
July 14, 2008

scopecontent.p: A longboat from the Christine Roberta stops to repair a cut leader. Inexperienced yachtsmen, flooding the coast during the summer months, represent a continuous problem for trap fishermen. Although each trap's exact position is marked on charts and hundreds of floats, barrels, and radar buoys make them visible, both sail and speedboats manage to run afoul. Yachtsmen cut their way out of their mistakes, leaving extra work and lost profits in their wakes.

did.unittitle:
Alan Wheeler supervises the deck work as a section of netting comes aboard,
June 6, 2008

scopecontent.p: Alan Wheeler supervises the deck work as a section of netting comes aboard. Concern over getting this task done safely left him uncharacteristically tense throughout the day, but having done it hundreds of times before, the job ran smoothly and without incident. Among the many other things to think about in the course of a day's fishing, all captains worry over the safety of their crew.

did.unittitle:
Dan MacDonald and Sammy Peters remove twine from the frame,
June 6, 2008

scopecontent.p: Dan MacDonald and Sammy Peters remove twine from the frame. Sammy, 87 years old, was the most senior man working traps during this particular season. Despite heart problems and several bouts with cancer, he drove to Sakonnet Point from Massachusetts to arrive at 5:30 each morning, usually the first of the crew on the scene. Left to right: Dan MacDonald, Sammy Peters.

did.unittitle:
View of a trap net stretched in an open field for cleaning and repair,
June 16, 2008

scopecontent.p: View of a trap net stretched in an open field for cleaning and repair. John Sousa works at a point almost exactly in the middle of the leader, which stretches to the truck at the far end of the field. Because the loss of twine during the summer can mean financial ruin, each trap company maintains spare twine that can replace netting catastrophically damaged during the fishing season.

did.unittitle:
John Sousa's hands have built and repaired untold thousands of yards of netting throughout his long career,
June 16, 2008

scopecontent.p: John Sousa's hands have built and repaired untold thousands of yards of netting throughout his long career. This is one of the important skills young fishermen no longer learn, as companies can no longer afford to employ them throughout the year. Corey Wheeler Forrest has learned many of these skills by working with older fishermen and also spends time repairing twine in the hot summer sun.

did.unittitle:
The Eagle rests at her mooring as the sun begins to burn through the early morning fog,
July 14, 2008

scopecontent.p: The Eagle rests at her mooring as the sun begins to burn through the early morning fog. As with most harbors, the number of working watercraft continues to dwindle, with pleasure boats filling the moorings left behind. This harbor is no different, as evidenced by the large yacht club just completed next to the trap companies' operations.

did.unittitle:
Portrait of Dan MacDonald,
April 27, 2008

scopecontent.p: Portrait of Dan MacDonald. Alan Wheeler loves to ski and works at a resort in the winter months up north. Dan is one of the snow-makers Alan brings south for the summer to work as crew on the Maria Mendonsa. For men and women who prefer to work outside, trap fishing provides the opportunity to fish without having to go offshore on extended trips.

did.unittitle:
Sully holds the longboats alongside the Mendonsa as she steams to the next trap,
June 19, 2008

scopecontent.p: Sully holds the longboats alongside the Mendonsa as she steams to the next trap. The water jetting from the ship's hull was used as coolant for the vessel's power plant. In this closed system, cold seawater passes through a heat exchanger mounted on the engine block before it is discharged back overboard. Alfred Sullivan.

did.unittitle:
Ian Campbell sits in the rain as the boat heads to the East Wall trap,
August 6, 2008

scopecontent.p: Ian Campbell sits in the rain as the boat heads to the East Wall trap. Two of North Star's leaders begin on the massive stonework forming the Harbor of Refuge. Construction on these breakwaters, nearly 13,000 feet in length, began in 1891 and finished in 1914, providing a safe haven for vessels traveling the coast. Using several million tons of stone, the breakwaters are 20 feet wide at the top and rise in places from waters 34 feet deep.

did.unittitle:
Anthony Parascandolo operates the ship's winch, lifting another load of scup from the sea,
May 3, 2008

scopecontent.p: Anthony Parascandolo operates the ship's winch, lifting another load of scup from the sea. In many ways, fishermen are much like farmers, even ignoring the obvious parallels in food production. Weather and other elements beyond their control often affect their livelihoods. In a few critical summer months, drastic changes in environmental conditions can seriously impact their ability to make a living. As with New England's farmers, fishermen are dependent on specific and expensive equipment to make thin profit margins work, and maintaining that equipment adds much to the overall cost. Finally, trap fishermen and farmers were once major food producers for the area, and both are rapidly disappearing from the Northeast.

did.unittitle:
Tom Hinckley and Saul Umana work together to keep their side of the parlor's twine above water,
June 23, 2008

scopecontent.p: Tom Hinckley and Saul Umana work together to keep their side of the parlor's twine above water. The netting used in traps is dipped in liquid tar, giving it a distinctive black color. Early on, tar preserved the cotton fibers from which twine was made. While twine made of nylon won't rot, this added layer of protection helps to reduce physical wear as well as UV damage from sunlight. Left to right: Tom Hinckley, Saul Umana.

did.unittitle:
Portrait of Rick Cambio,
June 5, 2008

scopecontent.p: Portrait of Rick Cambio. A career fisherman, Rick has worked on traps and as a draggerman far out to sea. This summer, after finishing the morning's work, Rick went to work cutting apart a wooden dragger that was no longer commercially viable. Point Judith's fleet has dwindled significantly over the course of the past ten years.

Adam and Sully clean the deck while James rests in the longboat. While younger crewmen generally chat on the way to the site, the more experienced members on deck seem always in motion, taking care of little details that assure a smooth day of fishing. Fish species appear at the same time each year with great predictability, as a trap fisherman of 1871 relates: "In the remarks of Mr. E. W. Whalley, of Narragansett Pier, we find a statement of the usual sequence of fish at Point Judith, and are presented at the same time with a most charming fragment of folk-lore. In reply to the inquiry as to whether fish were not earlier arrived at that point than usual, he replied: "About the same. They expected them in February and got the seines ready. They had them in the water in March. I always judge by the dandelions. When I see the first dandelion, scup come in; I watch the buds, and when the buds are swelled full then our traps go in; when the dandelion goes out of bloom and goes to seed, the scup are gone. That is true one year with another, though they vary with the season. I am guided by the blossoms of other kinds of plants for other fish. When high blackberries are in bloom we catch striped bass that weigh from 12 to 20 pounds. When the blue violets are in blossom—they come early—you can catch the small scoot-bass. That has always been my rule; that has been handed down by my forefathers." Left to right on deck: Adam Lotz, Alfred Sullivan.

did.unittitle:
Bucky Smith holds the twine in place as he waits for the signal to begin hauling,
June 23, 2008

scopecontent.p: Bucky Smith holds the twine in place as he waits for the signal to begin hauling. Commercial fishing is a rigorous game, better suited to the young and strong. With an average age of 55, a significant portion of New England's fishermen are now approaching retirement, leaving the industry with challenges in this arena as well. Captains often complain the trade is no longer passed to younger generations; finding young men or women with even the most basic skills has become nearly impossible. Roland Smith (Bucky).

did.unittitle:
Christine Roberta at her dock with thousands of pounds of scup in her pens,
May 3, 2008

scopecontent.p: Christine Roberta at her dock with thousands of pounds of scup in her pens. A conveyor will lift these fish into the packing building on the right. Trap companies in Rhode Island do not process their catch beyond simply packing them with ice into waterproof boxes. Others clean and fillet the fish later in the process of getting them to consumers.

did.unittitle:
Ian Campbell and Tom Hoxsie pull twine on the East Wall set,
June 4, 2008

scopecontent.p: Ian Campbell and Tom Hoxsie pull twine on the East Wall set. Tom, who has been trap fishing for more than twenty-five years, feels there may be a better future in harvesting fish by trap than by trawler. Low overhead and a green footprint could help revive the industry. Ian Campbell left, Tom Hoxsie right.

did.unittitle:
A lone sea robin swims towards the light, seeking a path out of the entrapping web,
May 1, 2008

scopecontent.p: A lone sea robin swims towards the light, seeking a path out of the entrapping web. A primitive-looking fish with a bony skull and sharp spines, they are beautiful when they spread their wing-like fins. Ian Campbell left, Tom Hoxsie right.

did.unittitle:
The Amelia Bucolo returns to Point Judith after hauling her trap,
June 23, 2008

scopecontent.p: The Amelia Bucolo returns to Point Judith after hauling her trap. Both the Bucolo and the Maria Mendonsa were built by Gladding and Hearn on the Taunton River in nearby Somerset, Massachusetts. Begun in 1955, the shipyard still builds steel and aluminum vessels, a rarity on the East Coast. The Bucolo, built in 1965, is still powered by her original Caterpillar 342 engine. Alan Glidden estimates her fuel consumption at five gallons per hour, burning a few hundred gallons every three weeks. Fishing, unlike many careers today, has always been a trade passed down by one generation to the next. Age and experience has taught youth and enthusiasm. While there are a few schools still offering some training in the business, most fishermen start on the back deck of a fishing boat willing to take them to sea. The fishing industry is democratic by nature. As a fisherman once told me, who you were, where you came from, or what you had previously done wasn't important. What mattered was how you did your job, and any fisherman who put in effort could expect to see results over time. Young workers once entered the trade dreaming of the vessel they would eventually command, and the majority of Rhode Island's fishing captains began their climb to the pilothouse from the lowest rung on the ladder.

did.unittitle:
Gear once again covers the wharf at the summer's end,
October 15, 2008

scopecontent.p: Gear once again covers the wharf at the summer's end. Anchors, buoys, nets, line, and the vessels themselves are retired for winter. The season ends abruptly when quotas for the year are filled. Once over, the crew's last job before dispersing is to gather back this gear. The twine is removed from the frames and brought ashore for drying and storage. Frames come next—the thousands of yards of line and the buoys that kept the trap afloat throughout the summer months. Finally, the 1,000-pound anchors are swung aboard for the trip back to their winter home along the waterfront. In the past, companies employed trap crews of hundreds of men on a year-round basis. They often fished a longer season when weather allowed, and when fishing ended, there were still new traps to build and twine to repair. Today, small crews disband and look for new work to tide them over the long winter months. Some stay within the fisheries while others go ashore to jobs with no ties to the sea. Yachts moored in the harbor begin to disappear as the winter intrudes, and Sakonnet Point settles into the role of icy gatekeeper at the mouth of the bay, quiet and deserted until spring arrives once again.

did.unittitle:
A Parascandolo & Sons Trap Company truck sits at a barn located a few miles from Sakonnet Point,
December 17, 2008

scopecontent.p: A Parascandolo & Sons Trap Company truck sits at a barn located a few miles from Sakonnet Point. The barn stores trap gear through the winter months. These stainless steel trailers are in big demand on the waterfront, not subject to the quick decay modern aluminum trailers face when exposed to the saltwater environment. Used not only to transport and store gear, many of them are refrigerated and hold daily catches until ready for shipment. As with any product, market prices vary with the demand for any particular species and the available supply. While allowed to catch fewer fish than in the past, higher prices in the marketplace for smaller quantities have helped offset some of the financial loss brought about by regulations. As waterfront property over the course of the last thirty years became more desirable, fishermen have been forced to move parts of their operations away from the ocean to more affordable locations, again increasing their costs. Housing for the wealthy continues to envelope the working waterfront and its supporting infrastructure. Newport, once a major fishing center, now caters only to yachtsmen and tourists. Even the loss of local hayfields to developers robs the trap fisherman of important space. Only time will tell how much longer this industry can survive.

did.unittitle:
The Maria Mendonsa's crew gathers the boats once again shortly after the morning's promising sunrise,
April 18, 2008

scopecontent.p: The Maria Mendonsa's crew gathers the boats once again shortly after the morning's promising sunrise. The future of fishing in New England remains uncertain. As regulations pile upon the fisheries in the few ports remaining on the Eastern Seaboard, fishermen leave the work of generations to head inland in hopes of earning a living with a more certain future. What we lose as a society when they leave goes beyond the ability to buy fresh seafood from local sources. While we can, for now at least, buy seafood farmed or fished from countries located around our shrinking globe, there will come a day when we can no longer afford to freight our dinners from a spot on the ocean 6,000 miles distant. Beyond these considerations, however, is the loss of yet another industry, another working culture, and the people who once toiled to provide food for the rest. Over the past thirty years, our country has shed these types of jobs and skills in a relentless quest for cheaper products, and as we now begin to discover, without work to do ourselves, we can no longer afford the products we now import. When a few large corporations finally control the industry, the small businesses that each boat represents will fade away, as will the jobs they provide. These are the type of men and women who built our country: independent, hardworking, and self-motivated, and we will all share in the loss when they no longer work our coastlines.

did.unittitle:
Janet circles her offshore trap during her last season as a working vessel,
May 23, 2008

scopecontent.p: Janet circles her offshore trap during her last season as a working vessel. Built in 1954 in Deltaville, Virginia, her previous owner attempted to sink her off Block Island. Forgetting to empty two large fuel tanks, Janet remained partially afloat and was towed back to shore. Ronnie Fatulie purchased her and after she was rebuilt, the Janet went on to fish traps for the Coast Canning Company for nearly 40 years. With opportunities fading in a sea of regulations, young fishermen no longer see possibilities. They are less and less the masters of their own fates, now subject to the bureaucracy that oversees them. Despite the many hurdles, fishermen remain an optimistic lot, and their enthusiasm for the work they do carries them through new challenges. While lifelong fisherman Joe Whaley sometimes feels he won't return to fishing, he nevertheless manages to leave the door open: "But after you did what you wanted all your life, without being told what to do, and all of a sudden somebody is trying to tell you what to do, where to go, how to do it, who to sell it to, what you can catch, when you can go, when you can come back, I said "Nope—you're not telling' me." But I'd love to go. I might get back in yet, I don't know. I still keep my Rhode Island permit...

did.unittitle:
The crew from the Christine Roberta heads out to sea under tow in their longboats for another day of fishing,
July 14, 2008

scopecontent.p: The crew from the Christine Roberta heads out to sea under tow in their longboats for another day of fishing. Other fishing vessels in the harbor include lobster boats and gill netters, although most of the harbor is now filled with yachts, displacing fishermen from the waterfront.

did.unittitle:
Crew from the Maria Mendonsa hauling twine at the trap,
April 27, 2008

Drawing of a typical Rhode Island Floating Trap,
December 17, 2008

scopecontent.p: Drawing of a typical Rhode Island Floating Trap. Note: This diagram is not to scale and does not include all anchors, floats, or weights used in the full construction of such a trap. The traps pictured throughout this book are known as floating traps, and while small differences in their construction may exist between the companies deploying them, every trap design is governed by the same general principle. Each is constructed around what fishermen call the frame of the structure, and the trap's netting hangs from this ridged form. The frame is formed by a series of anchors, lines, and buoys. Construction begins with a leader line anchored to either the shoreline or a breakwater. The leader may be as long as 1,500 feet, depending on local conditions and the overall size of the trap itself. This line is held on the surface of the ocean by a series of large floats, either steel spheres or barrels, brightly painted to warn passing maritime traffic of their location. The leader line stretches from the shore outward to the first float, which is itself held in place by a pair of anchors stretched perpendicular to the run of the leader. The cable proceeds to the next float anchored in the same fashion, continuing on to other floats until reaching the end of the leader some 1,500 feet later. The leader ends far from shore at the wings of the trap. The wings, set at an angle to the direction of both the leader and the trap itself, begin funneling fish into the structure. Swimming along the leader and directed by the wings, fish are then steered by the whiskers into the kitchen portion of the trap. A ramp made of netting rises from the ocean floor at the far end of the kitchen and leads them through the nozzle, the narrow entryway into the parlor. The parlor is the actual trap portion of the structure, the section from which fishermen will bail their catch. A rectangular box of netting up to 72' in width and 90' in length, the parlor stretches from the ocean's surface to the sea floor. Like the leader, these additional structures—the wings, the kitchen, and the parlor—are constructed using the same techniques. Lines running between anchored buoys trace each individual section across the ocean's surface, held in place by up to twenty-six anchors set in opposition to one another. Fishermen add rigidity to the framework by tensioning the anchor lines at each large float. Once the frame has been constructed, the netting, referred to as twine by fishermen, is ready to hang. The twine at the ocean's surface is strung with floats to keep fish from escaping over this edge. The bottom of the trap rests along the ocean's floor, held in place with lead, iron, or concrete weights specifically cast for this purpose. Once the entire frame is properly tensioned, fishermen hang twine from it to create the wings, the kitchen, and the parlor. Crewmen then hang twine from the leader line to complete the construction. As with the rest of the structure, the leader's twine must reach the bottom to prevent fish from merely swimming under. Because of this, the leader is tapered: narrow at the shore end and deepening as it moves offshore towards the trap. Once the twine is hung, the trap is left to soak—the fishermen's way of saying it has begun to fish. Drawing by Markham Starr.

did.unittitle:
Subseries 4.
Voices From The Waterfront: Portrait of the New Bedford Fishing Industry
files,
April 8, 2008 through 2010

scopecontent.p:
Files, primarily photographs, created during Starr's project. Also included is one inventory spreadsheet containing descriptive data for every photo and a digital copy of Starr's book
Voices From The Waterfront: Portrait of the New Bedford Fishing Industry
. The photo inventory mostly contains information also printed in the book.

arrangement.p: The digital files on disk have not been rearranged from their original order. The manuscript files have been described in alphabetical order in the finding aid and the photographs are listed in numerical order by ID number. The photographs' titles and ID numbers are copied from Starr's item level metadata in his photo inventory spreadsheet "Voices From the Waterfront Portraits From the New Bedford Fishing Industry.xls". The descriptions and listings of individuals in the photos were modified and used as titles. Sometimes additional information from the longer inventory descriptions was recorded in the item's Scope and Content note. All the descriptions were shortened from the versions in the inventory and the text printed in the project's book. The dates also come from the photo inventory. See the book, inventory, and files' metadata for more context.

did.unittitle:
Ted Pedersen, Richard Macleod, Robert Britto and John Isaksen. (Left to Right, Top to Bottom),
July 28, 2009

scopecontent.p: Ted Pedersen, Richard Macleod, Robert Britto and John Isaksen. (Left to Right, Top to Bottom) These four men are just a few of the thousands that have retired from a full life of fishing with the New Bedford fleet over the years. They present a typical cross section of the people involved through their personal histories and the stories they tell.

did.unittitle:
Richie & Ray Canastra: Owners of Whaling City Seafood Display Auction,
April 30, 2009

scopecontent.p: Richie & Ray Canastra: Owners of Whaling City Seafood Display Auction, they did over ninety million dollars of business in 2008. Trawlers and scallopers unload their catch at the waterfront facility where buyers can inspect the fish before the sale. Fish and scallop auctions are now held on-line and one hundred thousand pounds of scallops may be sold in five minutes. Once purchased, refrigerated trucks haul the cargo away.

did.unittitle:
Paul Lane: Shore captain for Lars Vinjerud's fleet,
May 21, 2009

scopecontent.p: Paul Lane: Shore captain for Lars Vinjerud's fleet. With a 200 ton captain's license, Lane currently manages plant operations, licensing for both the fleet and the fishermen aboard it, and attends the government conservation and fisheries management meetings as part of the operation. He wears many hats throughout the course of the day, and may be found working at jobs as diverse as driving a tractor trailer to Boston or installing a refrigeration unit in one of the vessels.

did.unittitle:
Chris Allerdt: Captain of F/V Morue,
April 30, 2009

scopecontent.p: Chris Allerdt: Captain of F/V Morue, Allerdt's grandfather and uncle both fished full time for a living, while his father fished for a short time both before and after his primary career. The Morue, French for codfish, is a typical dragger of the New Bedford fleet. While his two sons, both in college, seem headed for careers outside of the fishing industry, they often help him as needed with repairs when he returns to the dock.

did.unittitle:
Crista Bank: Research technician working on multi-species research at UMASS Dartmouth's School for Marine Science and Technology,
June 4, 2009

scopecontent.p: Crista Bank: Research technician working on multi-species research at UMASS Dartmouth's School for Marine Science and Technology. She has her 100 ton captain's license and previously worked as an observer on vessels for the National Marine Fisheries Services, recording information on species caught and the total catch of the ship. Having seen both sides of the issues involving fishing, she understands the mutual benefits that can occur when fishermen and scientists work together.

did.unittitle:
Johan Gundersen: Owner of Scandia Propeller and Supplies,
April 24, 2009

scopecontent.p: Johan Gundersen: Owner of Scandia Propeller and Supplies. Now running the business his father owned, Gundersen sells and repairs hydraulic systems and propellers for the fishing industry and does other light machining tasks. Scandia was one of the first shops on this coast to work installing hydraulic systems on fishing vessels. As with many other supporting industries in the port, Scandia Propeller is a family business, with three other family members working at the shop.

did.unittitle:
Roy Enoksen: While his father served in the US Navy during WWII, his family was forced to stay in Norway until the end of hostilities,
June 11, 2009

scopecontent.p: Roy Enoksen: While his father served in the US Navy during WWII, his family was forced to stay in Norway until the end of hostilities. After graduating from college, he began as a fisherman in the industry and bought his first boat at the age of thirty. After twenty years on the water he came ashore and he and his partner Frank O'Hara now run twenty-three scallop boats and employ over three hundred people in their operations. Both his son and son-in-law work in the business with him as well.

did.unittitle:
Kevin Dawson & Ann Jardin: The settlement company of Jardin and Dawson is housed in one of the oldest buildings in New Bedford,
April 30, 2009

scopecontent.p: Kevin Dawson & Ann Jardin: The settlement company of Jardin and Dawson is housed in one of the oldest buildings in New Bedford—the only building not burned to the ground by the British during the Revolutionary War. The settlement house determines how the proceeds from a trip are split amongst the crew and vessel and handles much of the paperwork fishermen do not have the time or inclination to do, allowing them to concentrate on the physical work of the fishing industry.

did.unittitle:
Charlie Mitchell: Captain and owner of the tugboat Jaguar,
May 5, 2009

scopecontent.p: Charlie Mitchell: Captain and owner of the tugboat Jaguar. After college and a stint as an officer in the navy, Mitchell worked with his father for a short while before getting into the tugboat business.

did.unittitle:
Charlotte Enoksen: Emigrating from Norway's Lofoten Islands, her father pursued the work of generations before him, owning two fishing vessels, the Porpoise and the Louise,
May 21, 2009

scopecontent.p: Charlotte Enoksen: Emigrating from Norway's Lofoten Islands, her father pursued the work of generations before him, owning two fishing vessels, the Porpoise and the Louise. Once married to a fisherman, Enoksen's poetry often revolves around their lives and those left on shore waiting for their return. Her work is both creative and cathartic, a "song without accompaniment." Now a social worker, she has also worked in journalism, advertising, public relations and fundraising.

did.unittitle:
Jim Dwyer: Head of the Lumpers Union,
April 24, 2009

scopecontent.p: Jim Dwyer: Head of the Lumpers Union. Lumpers are the men and women that off-load the vessel's fish when they return to port. The fish, stored iced in "pens" in the hold of the vessel, are placed by lumpers into vinyl baskets which hold 250 pounds before being hoisted from the ship. Dwyer puts together lumper crews whenever he gets a call to empty a newly arrived vessel.

did.unittitle:
Kristen Decas: Director of the Harbor Development Commission for the Port of New Bedford,
April 30, 2009

scopecontent.p: Kristen Decas: Director of the Harbor Development Commission for the Port of New Bedford, Decas is in charge of the physical infrastructure along the waterfront. Fishing piers, power and water supplying the fleet, and transportation routes throughout the waterfront are her responsibility, as well as assuring the fishermen have what they need to handle their catch on their return to port.

did.unittitle:
Paul Swain: Worked for the National Marine Fisheries Service for 40 years,
June 4, 2009

scopecontent.p: Paul Swain: Worked for the National Marine Fisheries Service for 40 years, and worked almost every other job the waterfront had to offer, from fishing to painting, lumping and icing to working the fish auction. His father, who emigrated from Newfoundland, was also a fisherman.

did.unittitle:
Sharon Cummings: Cummings has spent the last 34 years working as the secretary for the Fish Lumpers Pension and Welfare fund,
May 5, 2009

scopecontent.p: Sharon Cummings: Despite her father's efforts to keep her from working in the fishing industry, Cummings has spent the last 34 years working as the secretary for the Fish Lumpers Pension and Welfare fund, and thus has an intimate and widespread knowledge of the shoreside workings of the business.

did.unittitle:
Marty Olsen: Born in New Jersey in 1938, Olsen and his family moved to New Bedford in 1945 where his father worked as a fisherman,
May 14, 2009

scopecontent.p: Marty Olsen: Born in New Jersey in 1938, Olsen and his family moved to New Bedford in 1945 where his father worked as a fisherman. After serving in the Army, he began fishing in 1961 in a career that would last 35 years. While he went on a few scalloping trips, he was primarily a draggerman fishing out of both Boston and New Bedford. He was a longtime member of the New Bedford Fisherman's Union.

did.unittitle:
Eva Liput: Captain of F/V Quincy II, a 90' scallop boat,
June 4, 2009

scopecontent.p: Eva Liput: Captain of F/V Quincy II, a 90' scallop boat. Coming to this country from Poland as an art student in 1986, Liput went on to get her master's degree in fine art at Boston University before becoming a deckhand on a fishing vessel. She still pursues her art when time allows between the ten to fifteen day scalloping trips she takes. With a crew of seven men, the vessel brings back 18,000 pounds of scallops on a closed area trip, and more on the longer open area voyages.

did.unittitle:
Armando Estudante: His first visit to New Bedford in 1978 was because of his interest in Herman Melville,
June 11, 2009

scopecontent.p: Armando Estudante: His first visit to New Bedford in 1978 was because of his interest in Herman Melville. After finding people from his home town in New Bedford, he decided to emigrate to the US from Portugal where he ran a fleet of vessels for a fishing company. Opportunities for an entrepreneur in the US were greater than those in Portugal. Since he began fishing in this country, he has owned four vessels, and now fishes for both groundfish and scallops.

did.unittitle:
Jen, Karen & Bob Mitchell: The R.A. Mitchell Co. sells and repairs marine engines and generators used throughout the fishing fleet,
May 5, 2009

scopecontent.p: Jen, Karen & Bob Mitchell: Family businesses are common in the port. The R.A. Mitchell Co. sells and repairs marine engines and generators used throughout the fishing fleet. As he goes into semi-retirement, his two daughters are stepping into his shoes to continue on with the business, just as he did when his father retired from the company.

did.unittitle:
Tor, Kirsten, Reidar & Hans Bendiksen: Another family operation on the waterfront, Reidar's Manufacturing builds nets, dredges and other gear essential to the industry,
June 11, 2009

scopecontent.p: Tor, Kirsten, Reidar & Hans Bendiksen: Another family operation on the waterfront, Reidar's Manufacturing builds nets, dredges and other gear essential to the industry. With their long history in fishing, the Bendiksens have been able to create improvements to standard gear now widely used throughout the fleet. A blend of modern technology and old fashioned knowledge keep them in the forefront of fishing gear design.

did.unittitle:
Paul Anthony & John Liarikos: Sea Fuels delivers the diesel needed to power the vessels of the fleet,
May 5, 2009

scopecontent.p: Paul Anthony & John Liarikos: Sea Fuels delivers the diesel needed to power the vessels of the fleet. Oil is first delivered by truck to large tanks on the waterfront. It is then pumped into their barge where it can be off-loaded into both trawlers and scallopers along the docks. Sea Fuels delivered three and a half million gallons in 2008, and also fills the barges of other fuel companies within the port.

did.unittitle:
Lou Lagace: Owner and "truck" captain of the F/V Mariette,
April 30, 2009

scopecontent.p: Lou Lagace: While the majority of vessels fishing from New Bedford are trawlers and scallopers, there are other fisheries. He is owner and "truck" captain of the F/V Mariette. A truck captain remains on shore taking care of the other side of the business, but often spells the working captain of the ship. He is pictured here atop the 17,000 lb. dredge used to harvest surf clams.

did.unittitle:
Toby Lees: Captain and owner of F/V Seel, a 90' dragger,
April 24, 2009

scopecontent.p: Toby Lees: Graduated from URI's Commercial Fisheries and Marine Technology Department in 1971 and began fishing out of New Bedford after having spent a semester on a New Bedford boat. Captain and owner of F/V Seel, a 90' dragger, Lees fishes the New England Coast for groundfish, including cod, haddock, flounder and other species.

did.unittitle:
Mathieu Lemieux: Along with his father Paul, Lemeiux owns and operates Blue Fleet Welding Company,
April 30, 2009

scopecontent.p: Mathieu Lemieux: Along with his father Paul, Lemeiux owns and operates Blue Fleet Welding Company. His primary business is to build scallop dredges for the extensive scalloping fleet of the port. His company also welds together other heavy equipment used within the fishing industry, employing ten people on a full time basis.

did.unittitle:
Carlos Alberto: Manager and part owner of Luzo's Fishing Gear, Inc.,
May 14, 2009

scopecontent.p: Carlos Alberto: Manager and part owner of Luzo's Fishing Gear, Inc., a company that employs ten people and provides the fishing industry with fuel as well as with almost any type of gear or hardware a vessel may require. Growing up on a farm in Portugal and eventually becoming an engineer, Alberto had no previous exposure to the fishing industry prior to emigrating to the United States, and has preferred staying ashore with his family in the supply business to the life of a fisherman at sea.

did.unittitle:
Phil Ashworth: A self-described poet-fisherman,
October 29, 2009

scopecontent.p: Phil Ashworth: A self-described poet-fisherman, Ashworth was born in 1958 and left high school at age eighteen to launch his fishing career. He began on draggers, but switched to the more lucrative scallop boats when an opportunity presented itself. He worked his way up from the bottom of the hierarchy—from shoveling rocks off the deck, to the position of cook, and finally to the position of first mate. Ashworth recounts several of his memorable experiences

did.unittitle:
Donald Clattenburg: Born in Port Midway, Nova Scotia, Donald Clattenburg came to New Bedford in 1941,
May 25, 2009

scopecontent.p: Donald Clattenburg: Born in Port Midway, Nova Scotia, Donald Clattenburg came to New Bedford in 1941. The son of a fishing captain, he started out working in a fillet house and then served on LST 1014 in the Navy during WWII. After the war he returned to fishing with both his father and his uncle. In 1966, while aboard the F/V Venture, Clattenburg was caught in a terrible storm and badly injured. He was rescued by the crew of a nearby Russian factory trawler.

did.unittitle:
Kevin Stokesbury: Research scientist at UMASS Dartmouth's School for Marine Science and Technology where he works with the fishing industry to create sustainable fishing practices,
June 11, 2009

scopecontent.p: Kevin Stokesbury: Research scientist at UMASS Dartmouth's School for Marine Science and Technology where he works with the fishing industry to create sustainable fishing practices. Using cameras lowered to the ocean floor, Dr. Stokesbury has mapped quantities of scallops by location, allowing for an increase in the yearly catch while monitoring the overall health of the stock. His work demonstrates what can happen in a cooperative effort between fishermen and scientists.

did.unittitle:
Lillian Riveira,
November 5, 2009

scopecontent.p: Lillian Riveira: Born and raised in El Salvador, Riveira only recently came to this country, emigrating in 2006. She began working at American Pride Seafoods performing many of the tasks associated with the creation of the final product and its packaging for shipment around the country. American Pride Seafoods takes the fish from the vessel to the table with its numerous products, including ten species of fish either harvested directly from the ocean or raised on farms.

did.unittitle:
Betsy Pye,
October 29, 2009

scopecontent.p: Betsy Pye: While she was born and raised in New Bedford, she had, like many others, no real connection to the town's major industry until she married a fisherman. The life of a fisherman's wife is often quite different from that of someone whose husband has a more typical nine to five job. To keep the household running smoothly, she often takes up duties he might cover were he home. Pye works at the New Bedford Ocean Explorium.

did.unittitle:
Chris Wright: Captain F/V Huntress and F/V Harvester,
April 24, 2009

scopecontent.p: Chris Wright: Captain F/V Huntress and F/V Harvester. Born in New Bedford and raised in Fairhaven, both his father and grandfather worked in the industry. He is a graduate of the Massachusetts Maritime Academy, and has worked for the same owner for most of his career, and as captain for the last twenty-two years. He has also owned, in partnership, various scallop boats, upgrading them as opportunity allowed. Recently he sold his share in the last of these vessels.

did.unittitle:
Joe Swift: Owner of Crystal Ice Company,
November 5, 2009

scopecontent.p: Joe Swift: Owner of Crystal Ice Company, he supplies the New Bedford fishing fleet as well as vessels from other ports with the crushed ice used to refrigerate the catch in ship's holds until their return to the docks.

did.unittitle:
Ted Pedersen,
May 25, 2009

Robert Britto,
May 25, 2009

Carlos Rafael: Fleet owner,
May 21, 2009

scopecontent.p: Carlos Rafael: Fleet owner. Emigrated from Portugal as a young man in 1968, and worked various jobs before getting into the fishing business as a cutter. He worked his way through the industry until branching out on his own, buying and selling fish, before buying his first boat. He now owns 40 fishing vessels, both draggers and scallopers, a fish house and a warehouse, and can be found on the pier overseeing all aspects of the operation, from a vessel's modernization to its daily operation.

did.unittitle:
John Isaksen,
May 25, 2009

Jeff Ferreira: Ferreira's company, F&B Rubberized, cuts rubber chafing pieces and rollers from tires to be used on the bottom edges of nets and dredges,
May 14, 2009

scopecontent.p: Jeff Ferreira: As cars run on rubber tires, so do the majority of nets and dredges used throughout the fishing industry. Ferreira's company, F&B Rubberized, cuts rubber chafing pieces and rollers from tires to be used on the bottom edges of nets and dredges, preventing wear and allowing the gear to roll across the ocean floor. With over thirty employees, his business recycles tens of thousands of tires a year, keeping them from landfills and extending their useful lifespan.

did.unittitle:
Richard Macleod,
May 25, 2009

Laurie Botelho: Botelho's company, Diamond Marine, produces the cotton bags used to store scallops aboard ships at sea,
April 24, 2009

scopecontent.p: Laurie Botelho: Botelho's company, Diamond Marine, produces the cotton bags used to store scallops aboard ships at sea. The material is cut and sewn into bags which must hold a specific number of pounds of scallops. These special bags allow the scallop meats to both breath and drain, creating the highest quality product available. Coming from the food industry, Botelho's long interest in food safety leads her to design a more bacterial resistant product, assuring the highest prices for fishermen at auction.

did.unittitle:
Tove Bendiksen: As an educator in Fairhaven, she works to promote a better understanding of the industry not only within area schools, but also as a Park Ranger leading "dock walks" in the summer for the local population or tourists visiting the area,
May 25, 2009

scopecontent.p: Tove Bendiksen: Born into a family with a long history in fishing, not only did her father fish, but both grandfathers and an uncle as well. Her two brothers and her father work designing and building gear for the industry in their family owned business. As an educator in Fairhaven, she works to promote a better understanding of the industry not only within area schools, but also as a Park Ranger leading "dock walks" in the summer for the local population or tourists visiting the area.

did.unittitle:
Deb and Ron Shrader: After meeting her husband Ronnie, a scallop captain, Shrader started the non-profit organization Shore Support, and along with other members from the board created the Fishermen's Emergency Relief Fund in 2005,
May 14, 2009

scopecontent.p: Deb and Ron Shrader: After meeting her husband Ronnie, a scallop captain, Shrader started the non-profit organization Shore Support, and along with other members from the board created the Fishermen's Emergency Relief Fund in 2005. This fund provided support to sustain fishing families in times of crisis. In 2007 she testified before the United States Congress regarding the reauthorization of the Magnuson Stevens Act.

did.unittitle:
Series 3. 2018 accrual:
In History's Wake: The Last Trap Fishermen of RI
moving images,
circa 2010 through 2018

scopecontent.p:
Accrual is 25 moving images and 1 manuscript. The moving images are part of Starr's documentary project
In History's Wake: The Last Trap Fishermen of RI
. He has described them into two subseries: technical films and general audience films. The technical films are narrated by Starr. Starr uses moving images and words to explain the technical processes of trap fishing. The general audience films are narrated by interviewees and depict them at work. Films vary in length from 2 minutes to 79 minutes. The film inventory "FILES.docx" features Starr's explanation of his motivations and inspirations to make the films.

arrangement.p: Films are listed in alphabetical order. Archivists repurposed Starr's descriptions from the film inventory "FILES.docx" into the item-level titles and Scope and Content notes. The films and document are all in one folder. Listed durations are in H:MM:SS format.

processinfo.p: Julia Kim renamed the files from the donor's original descriptive titles to standardized AFC MV numbers in 2018, and Charles Hosale renamed the files back to the original names in December 2020. Charles Hosale added "FILES.docx" to the series in November 2020. It had previously been stored separately.

did.unittitle: Film inventory
Subseries 1. General audience films

title.part: Fishing at Sakonnet Point

scopecontent.p: This five minute film was made for a fisherman to show to his child's school classroom. It shows the boat going out, emptying a trap, returning to the dock, and packing out the fish for shipment. Best film for a quick overview of trap fishing. Filmed aboard the Maria Mendonsa. No narration.

did.unittitle:
In History's Wake: The Trap Fishermen of Rhode Island
(Final cut - short version)

descriptivenote.p: In History's Wake The Trap Fishermen of RI short version.mov

scopecontent.p: This shorter version was made from the longer version to show a general audience. It follows the fishermen through their summer's work, but only includes one boat fishing. Because of this, a lot of narration by the fishermen in the longer version was also cut. Does not include removing gear at the end of the season. Narrated by the fishermen themselves. The fishermen's narration does not generally involve the technical aspects of building and fishing a floating trap.

did.unittitle:
In History's Wake: The Trap Fishermen of Rhode Island
(Long version)

descriptivenote.p: In Historys Wake The Trap Fishermen of RI long version.mov

scopecontent.p: This is the longest film and was made for the trap fishermen themselves. It includes operations from nearly all of the summer's work, beginning with spring preparations. It does not include footage of removing and storing the gear at the end of the season. It is completely narrated by the fishermen themselves, and shows all three boats fishing. As it is a bit long for a general audience, a second and reduced version was made showing only one boat fishing. The fishermen's narration does not generally involve the technical aspects of building and fishing a floating trap, but rather, their lives in fishing and comments on the industry in general.

did.unittitle: Subseries 2. Technical films

title.part: Alan Glidden Fishing the Black Point Trap

descriptivenote.p: alan glidden fishing the black point trap.mov

scopecontent.p: This film follows the Amelia Bucolo through a typical day's fishing. Narration by Markham Starr.

title.part: Emptying the Black Point Trap

scopecontent.p: This film covers Alan Glidden's crew as they empty their trap. This was filmed from one of the nozzle boat, rather than from the deck of the Amelia Bucolo. Narrated by Markham Starr.

title.part: Fishing in May

scopecontent.p: Another day fishing on the Mendonsa with Alan Wheeler and his crew. Narrated by Markham Starr.

title.part: Fishing on the Maria Mendonsa

scopecontent.p: Another day fishing down at Sakonnet Point. Narrated by Markham Starr.

title.part: Hanging Twine on the Black Point Trap

descriptivenote.p: Hanging Twine on the Black Point Trap.mov

scopecontent.p: This film was shot from the deck of the Amelia Bucolo as crew members installed the twine for the trap into the existing framework, previously anchored into position. Narration by Markham Starr. This film was shot from a distance so it is harder to see the finer details of installing a trap. Other films covering the same operation make it easier to see.

title.part: High Speed Hoxsie

scopecontent.p: This humorous film is a two-minute version of "North Star Fishing the East Wall Trap". It is essentially the same film run at high speed and was made as a joke for Tom and his crew. No narration, set to music.

did.unittitle:
In History's Wake: The Trap Fishermen of Rhode Island
(Starr narration)

scopecontent.p: Version of Starr's film featuring Starr's technical narration. Starr explains the actions the fishermen are taking and how their equipment functions.

title.part: Installing a Trap

scopecontent.p: This is the best footage of Tom and his crew installing a trap's twine into an existing framework. This is probably the most complex part of the process, and was filmed from the skiff carrying the twine. This video starts with a 3D drawing of a trap in the water. Narrated by Markham Starr.

title.part: North Star Fishing 1

scopecontent.p: This day was filmed in the summer of 2016 and follows the North Star and her crew as they empty their traps in the Harbor of Refuge at Point Judith. Narrated by Markham Starr.

title.part: North Star Fishing 2

scopecontent.p: A typical day fishing on the North Star, including transferring two sharks to a truck sent by the Mystic Aquarium for that purpose. Traps often catch specific fish for aquariums in the United States. Narrated by Markham Starr.

title.part: North Star Fishing 3

scopecontent.p: This film covers a morning's work bailing the fish from Tom Hoxsie's traps. Filmed in the fog and narrated by Markham Starr.

title.part: North Star Fishing the East Wall Trap

descriptivenote.p: North Star Fishing the East Wall Trap.mov

scopecontent.p: Tom Hoxsie and the crew on the North Star bail one of his three traps. Filmed from the breakwater in the Harbor of Refuge rather than from the boat itself.

title.part: Pogies

scopecontent.p: This film covers a day fishing on the Maria Mendonsa. The primary catch for the day were pogies, an oily and bony fish used as lobster bait by local fishermen. Narrated by Markham Starr.

title.part: Pulling the Gear for the Season

descriptivenote.p: Pulling the gear for the Season.mov

scopecontent.p: Alan Wheeler and his crew pulls gear out of the ocean in the fall at the end of the 2015 fishing season. Narrated by Markham Starr.

title.part: Removing a Trap for Cleaning

scopecontent.p: This film covers Alan Wheeler and the crew of the Maria Mendonsa removing a dirty trap from a frame for cleaning. About once a month, each trap and leader is replaced with a clean and repaired version, as twine covered in weeds fishes poorly and becomes too heavy for the crew to handle. The dirty twine is brought to shore to dry out the weeds and to repair any holes or other damage. Narrated by Markham Starr.

title.part: Removing the Leader's Twine

scopecontent.p: The Amelia Bucolo's crew removes a dirty leader from the trap framework for cleaning.

title.part: Spring Preparations

scopecontent.p: This short film covers some of the work that occurs before the traps are placed into the ocean. Each of the three boats trap fishing are represented. Nets not repaired over the winter are finished, boats and gear are painted, and engines are overhauled. Narration by Markham Starr.

title.part: The Amelia Bucolo Empties Her Trap

descriptivenote.p: The Amelia Bucolo Empties her Trap.mov

scopecontent.p: Alan Glidden and his crew haul their trap. Narration by Markham Starr.

title.part: Tom Hoxsie Setting a Frame into Position

descriptivenote.p: Tom Hoxsie Setting a Frame into Position.mov

scopecontent.p: This film covers Tom Hoxsie on the North Star anchoring the second of three frames into position. Narration by Markham Starr.

title.part: Trap Fishing on the Amelia Bucolo

descriptivenote.p: Trap Fishing on the Amelia Bucolo.mov

scopecontent.p: This is the same film used in both the long and short version of In History's Wake, set to music with no narration. This was made for the fishermen of this vessel to show their friends and family their particular fishing operation.

title.part: Trap Fishing on the Maria Mendonsa

descriptivenote.p: Trap Fishing on the Maria Mendonsa.mov

scopecontent.p: This is the same film used in both the long and short version of In History's Wake, set to music with no narration. This was made for the fishermen of this vessel to show their friends and family their particular fishing operation.

title.part: Trap Fishing on the North Star

descriptivenote.p: Trap Fishing on the North Star.mov

scopecontent.p: This is the same film used in both the long and short version of In History's Wake, set to music with no narration. This was made for the fishermen of this vessel to show their friends and family their particular fishing operation.

did.unittitle:
Series 4. 2019 accrual: Interview transcripts and sound recordings,
circa 2005 through 2019

scopecontent.p:
Accrual is 8 sound recordings, 1 moving image, and 3 manuscripts. The sound recordings are interviews with Rhode Island trap fishermen. Starr indicates that these recordings were conducted separately from his
In History's Wake: The Last Trap Fishermen of RI
project. There are no transcripts for the audio and video recordings and the recordings are undated. Two of the manuscript documents contain full transcripts of interviews conducted for two documentary projects:
Finest Kind: The Lobstermen of Corea Maine
and
In History's Wake: The Last Trap Fishermen of RI
. The audio recordings that correspond to these interview transcriptions are not part of this collection. The third manuscript document (afc2013031_Interview_Descriptions.doc) contains descriptions of the interviews in the sound recordings and documents.

arrangement.p:
The films and documents are all in one folder. Files are described in alphabetical order by format. Archivists repurposed Starr's descriptions into item-level Scope and Content notes. Descriptions for all but one of the files and interviews are in "afc2013031_Interview_Descriptions.doc". Starr did not provide a description of the interview with Andy Mannix,
A Day at Sea on the F/V Lady Jane
.

processinfo.p: Julia Kim prepended "afc2013031_" to the original filenames. Charles Hosale added the manuscript documents to the series in November 2020. The documents had previously been stored separately.

title.part: A Day at Sea on the F/V Lady Jane

scopecontent.p:
Photograph slideshow and audio interview with Marshfield MA fisherman Andy Mannix entitled
A Day at Sea on the F/V Lady Jane
. There is no transcript for this recording.

did.unittitle:
Corea Maine lobstermen interview transcripts,
July 2010

scopecontent.p: Full transcripts of interviews conducted for "Finest Kind: The Lobstermen of Corea Maine." Document contains text for twelve interviews conducted in July 2010. The audio recordings that correspond to these interview transcriptions are not part of this collection. The interview transcripts also appear in whole or part in Starr's book "Finest Kind: The Lobstermen of Corea Maine."

did.unittitle: Interview descriptions

Trap fisherman interview transcripts,
2009

scopecontent.p:
Full transcripts of interviews conducted for
In History's Wake: The Last Trap Fishermen of RI
. Document contains text of four interviews conducted summer 2009. The audio recordings that correspond to these interview transcriptions are not part of this collection. The interview transcripts also appear in whole or part in Starr's book
In History's Wake: The Last Trap Fishermen of RI
.

did.unittitle: Interview with Stesha Campbell

scopecontent.p: Stesha Cambell was one of only a handful of women working in the fishing industry on the deck of a boat at the time of the recording. While she grew up near the ocean's edge, she didn't come from a traditional fishing background. The boat her brother was working on needed an extra hand, and she decided to give it a try, and has been working as a commercial fisherman ever since. Starting out on Tom Hoxsie's trap fishing boat, she then joined her brother in starting an oyster farm in the bay above the harbor. A few years later, they bought some of the floating fish traps from Tom and their own boat, and now trap throughout the summer months along with the oystering. At home wherever she lands, Stesha has blended into the fishing community and describes the operations in which she is now involved and how she got into them in this recording.

did.unittitle: Interview with Cory Wheeler Forest

scopecontent.p: Cory Wheeler Forest is one of Alan Wheeler's two children who work with him operating a floating fish trap company in Sakonnett, Rhode Island. While not interested in the operation until her teenage years, Cory became and avid fisherman once she began going out on the boat as a deckhand. (Cory, like most women who fish commercially, generally prefer to be called fishermen, not fisherwomen.) She is a part owner of the company and works on all aspects of the business: fishing, mending twine, and importantly, selling all that they catch to markets in Boston, New York and other places. In this recording Cory talks about her life in the industry and the problems they face in today's world running an operation that has changed little in the past 100 years.

did.unittitle: Interview with Tom Hoxsie

scopecontent.p: As with most commercial fishermen in Point Judith, Tom comes from a fishing family and grew up on the local waters. After high school, he tried working at Electric Boat building submarines and in a local boatyard before realizing he didn't want to work for others, and returned to fishing as a way to make a living. The fishermen of Point Judith are nothing if not versatile, and Tom was no exception, working in all types of fisheries before settling into the trapping industry for most of his career. Tom has owned and operated a floating trap company since the death of his brother in the early '80s, and began his own oyster farm in the bay above the docks to keep himself on the water. Tom describes his early and rough start into full-time commercial fishing, and the reasons he works to provide food for others in this recording.

did.unittitle: Interview with James Main

scopecontent.p: James was awakened by his father at the age of 10 and told he was going fishing, and he has made a living on the water ever since. Mostly fishing offshore, he worked in nearly all types of fisheries. In his later years, he became the captain of the Amelia Bucollo, a trap fishing boat out of Point Judith, Rhode Island. Trap fishing is a great way for older fishermen to partly retire from the long trips and grueling work of the offshore fisheries. The season only covers the summer months, and the boat leaves the dock at 6 AM and the day's work is usually over by mid to late morning. In this recording, James talks about his life on the water and the fisheries in which he participated.

did.unittitle: Interview with George Mendonsa

scopecontent.p: George Mendonsa is the sailor everyone has seen photos of but few know. Most famously, he was the sailor in Alfred Eisenstaedt's photo for Life Magazine taken in Times Square at the end of WWII of the sailor kissing the nurse. While less famous nationally, George and his brothers were quite famous as the floating trap fishermen of Rhode Island. After immigrating to the US at the beginning of the 20th century, George and his family grew up on a small island off of Newport, Rhode Island. His father was the captain of a small floating fish trap company, and George grew up living and breathing fish. In this recording George talks about fishing, his role in the war and his famous kiss, and the millions of pounds of fish he and his brothers caught for others to eat.

did.unittitle: Interview with Joe Whaley

scopecontent.p: Joe Whaley's father was born in the Point Judith lighthouse, and Joe spent his entire life on the water in the commercial fishing industry. He began when small, wooden boats were the standard in the Port of Point Judith, Rhode Island, and saw the many changes that overtook the port as it grew into the 9th largest fishing port in America. For much of his career, he fished with his wife Midge as his deckhand, an unusual arrangement in a male dominated industry. Typical of most Point Jude fishermen, Joe worked in a variety of fisheries throughout his life, and also worked for AT&T at sea protecting trans-Atlantic cables when broken or as they were installed, keeping fishing vessels away from the ongoing work. In this recording Joe describes his life at sea and the governmental changes that caused him to quit.

did.unittitle: Interview with Alan Wheeler

scopecontent.p: Alan Wheeler is a second generation fisherman working out of Sakonnett Point, Rhode Island. His father began trucking vegetables and eventually fish off Aquidneck Island before buying a fish trap company. He and two of his children still operate a Rhode Island style floating fish trap, one of only three companies still utilizing this ancient technology. Alan has also worked in numerous other fisheries, such as lobstering, gillnetting, and longlining. In this recording Alan talks about his life in fishing and the operation of the fish traps they still work.

did.unittitle: Interview with Luke Wheeler

scopecontent.p: Luke is Alan Wheeler's oldest son, and has been an avid commercial fisherman since he was a child. He began by fishing with his father, lobstering from a skiff and eventually going out on the trap boat. Today he also owns and operates the Shirley Ann, a gillnetter out of Sakonnet Point, Rhode Island, as well as working with his sister and father to run the floating trap company they own amongst themselves. In this recording Luke talks about his upbringing on the water and his path through the Merchant Marine Academy and back onto the decks of fishing vessels. He also describes how a floating fish trap works.

did.unittitle:
Series 5. 2020 accrual: Independent films,
circa 2010 through 2019

scopecontent.p: Accrual is 29 moving images and 1 manuscript. The films were shot and edited by Starr. 28 of them concern fishing and one concerns dairy farming. The films vary in length from four minutes to one hour and fifteen minutes. The independent films were not created in association with any of Starr's broader documentary projects, but they do compliment those works. The fishing films primarily profile individual fishermen or small businesses, while a few concern the northeastern fishing industry more broadly. The dairy film is a profile of Clark Woodmansee, a Preston, Connecticut, farmer. Some of the films are derivative versions of others - for example, a shorter cut intended for a different audience. The films are undated but appear to have been shot circa 2010-2019. The manuscript is Starr's film inventory, which includes his descriptions for all the films.

arrangement.p: The films and document are stored in one folder. Files are described in alphabetical order (aside from the film inventory, which is listed first). Archivists repurposed Starr's descriptions in the film inventory into titles and Scope and Content notes.

did.unittitle:
Film inventory,
November 8, 2019

descriptivenote.p: Descriptions of the films on this hard drive.txt

title.part: Andrea Incollingo and the Founding of The Bait Company

descriptivenote.p: Andrea Incollingo and the Founding of The Bait Company.m2t

scopecontent.p: Andrea founded the Bait Company in 1984 to provide lobstermen with a convenient source for their bait. She narrates her crazy entry into the world of commercial fishermen and what the company has meant to her over time.

title.part: Charlie Brayton: A Life at Sea

descriptivenote.p: Charlie Brayton A Life at Sea.mp4

scopecontent.p: This is a shorter version of "Charlie Brayton: Life of a Fisherman," made for a general audience.

title.part: Charlie Brayton: Life of a Fisherman

descriptivenote.p: Charlie Breyton Life of a Fisherman.m2t

scopecontent.p: Charlie discusses his lifetime in various fishing industries and the challenges he has faced as he fishes for bait and ground fish off Block Island.

title.part: Clark Woodmansee: Life of a Dairyman

descriptivenote.p: Clark Woodmansee Life of a Dairyman.m2ts

scopecontent.p: Clark Woodmansee, along with his son, operates a dairy farm in Preston, Connecticut. Clark narrates his family's history in the business, the daily operation of the farm, and the challenges they face as they struggle to keep alive in a world of corporations. Narrated against a backdrop of daily life on the farm.

title.part: David Gallop and the RI Engine Company

descriptivenote.p: David Gallup and The RI Engine Co.mp4

scopecontent.p: David and his brother Jay operate the RI Engine Company, started by their grandfather in 1947. It remains an essential operation for the fishermen of the port. David discusses the company history and what they do over scenes of the work being done at the business.

did.unittitle:
David Gallup and the Rhode Island Engine Company
(longer version)

descriptivenote.p: David Gallup and RI Engine Company long version.mp4

scopecontent.p: This is a longer version of "David Gallop and the RI Engine Company" containing a little more information for historical purposes.

title.part: Gillnetting on the F/V Oceana

scopecontent.p: Dean Pesante describes his life in the fishery and how gillnetting works as a fishery. Narrated against a backdrop of a day-trip fishing out of the port.

title.part: Impressions From a Fishing Port

scopecontent.p: Video impressions of Point Judith set to music made for a general audience.

title.part: Jenn Fish: A Life in the Commercial Fisheries

descriptivenote.p: Jenn Fish A life in the Commercial Fisheries.m2t

scopecontent.p: Jenn comes from a long line of fishermen, but is one of the few women fishing out of the port. Jenn discusses how she got into the fishery and the challenges she faces against the backdrop of a day's trip fishing for squid in Block Island Sound.

title.part: Joan Booth of The Bait Company

descriptivenote.p: Joan Booth of The Bait Company.m2t

scopecontent.p: Joan narrates what it is like to string bait for commercial lobstermen as an employee of The Bait Company.

title.part: Lobster Fishing on the Erica Knight

descriptivenote.p: Lobster Fishing on the Erica Knight.m2ts

scopecontent.p: Mark Sweitzer discusses his unlikely path into the industry and how he fishes for lobsters in Rhode Island waters, set against a day's trip lobstering.

title.part: Lobster Fishing on the F/V Select

descriptivenote.p: Lobster Fishing on the FV Select.mp4

scopecontent.p: This film follows Rich Lodge as he fishes for lobster on a day trip off Block Island. Rich discusses all aspects of the business and his life in the fisheries.

title.part: Mark Sweitzer: A Life in the Lobster Fishery

descriptivenote.p: MarkSwietzer A life in the Lobster Fishery.mp4

scopecontent.p: A shortened version of "Lobster Fishing on the Erica Knight" - made for a general audience.

title.part: Martha Blackett of the Bait Company

descriptivenote.p: Martha Blackett of The Bait Company.m2t

scopecontent.p: Martha narrates what it is like to string bait for commercial lobstermen as an employee of The Bait Company.

title.part: Mike Marchetti: The Waterman

scopecontent.p: A shortened version of "Scalloping on Point Judith Pond with Mike Marchetti" - made for a general audience.

title.part: Narragansett Bay Lobsters, Inc.

scopecontent.p: Documents the daily operations of a typical fish dealer situated right on the docks in Point Judith. Although they began as a lobster dealer, out of necessity, they have moved into the fish business as well. Narrated by Adam Morse, the owner, with scenes from daily operations behind his voice.

title.part: Oyster Farming on Point Judith Pond with Ian Campbell

descriptivenote.p: Oyster Farming on Point Judith Pond with Ian Campbell.m2ts

scopecontent.p: Ian, along with his sister Stesha, started and run their own oyster farm. Ian narrates how he got into fishing to begin with and then into oystering with his sister. They discuss their methodologies, trials and tribulations in this business as they spend a day on the farm.

title.part: Oyster Farming on Point Judith Pond with Stesha Campbell

descriptivenote.p: Oyster Farming on Point Judith Pond with Stesha Campbell.m2ts

scopecontent.p: Stesha, along with her brother Ian, started and run their own oyster farm. Stesha narrates how she got into fishing to begin with and then into oystering with Ian. They discuss their methodologies, trials and tribulations in this business as they spend a day on the farm. Stesha is one of only a few women fishing out of Point Judith.

title.part: Pete Hanson: 53 Years a Machinist

scopecontent.p: Pete Hanson talks about his life as a machinist for the Rhode Island Engine Company, one of the most essential companies in Point Judith. Pete discusses evolution in equipment design and the work the company still does today. Background film is of Pete working in the shop.

title.part: Point Judith: Portraits From a Fishing Port

descriptivenote.p: Point Jude Portraits From a Fishing Port.mp4

scopecontent.p: An overall look at Point Judith as a commercial fishing port - meant for a general audience.

title.part: Rodman Sykes: A Life in the Fisheries

descriptivenote.p: Rodman Sykes A Life in the Fisheries 1 26 17 bright.m2t

scopecontent.p: This film follows Rodman and his deckhand on a day trip as he narrates his families' history in the industry and his lifetime spent on the water. Rodman is one of the most highly respected fishermen in the port.

title.part: Scalloping on Point Judith Pond with Mike Marchetti

descriptivenote.p: Scalloping on Point Judith Pond with Mike Marchetti.m2ts

scopecontent.p: Mike discusses his life in commercial fishing as he fishes for bay scallops.

title.part: 6 Boats in 8.5 Minutes

scopecontent.p: This video was produced to run at a fishing festival and show the general public day trips on 6 different vessels involved in different fisheries- lobstering, squid fishing, scalloping, gillnetting, trawling for baitfish, and trapfishing. Silent film.

title.part: Stesha

scopecontent.p: This short film was made to help promote women in the commercial fishing industry. Stesha Campbell discusses how she got into commercial fishing and what she likes about the work.

title.part: Stesha Campbell: Learning the Ropes

scopecontent.p: Stesha Campbell began her fishing career when asked by her brother if she would like to take a vacated position on the fishing vessel North Star. She began working on the floating fish traps with no prior fishing experience, and went on further to help her brother with his new venture in farming shellfish on Point Judith bay. Stesha narrates this film and discusses learning the business from scratch.

title.part: The RI Engine Company

scopecontent.p: Jay Gallup and his brother David operate the RI Engine Company, started by their grandfather in 1947. It remains an essential operation for the fishermen of the port. In this version Jay Gallup discusses the company history and what they do over scenes of the work being done at the business.

title.part: Trap Fishing on the Buckeye

scopecontent.p: A quick video of a trip to empty floating trap sites at Point Judith, RI. Ian and his sister Stesha Campbell bought some of Tom Hoxsie's trap sites as Tom became seriously ill with cancer and Ian did not want to see these historic sites disappear forever. This film has no narration.

title.part: Trawlworks

scopecontent.p: Trawlworks builds and sells gear to commercial fishermen out of Point Judith. This film is narrated by several of the primary workers as they go about building nets for trawling. One of two companies in the area, they are essential to the operation of the port.

title.part: Wayne Gaumond: 32 Years Lumping

scopecontent.p: Wayne has been employed for most of his working life as a lumper in Point Judith. Lumpers unload fish from ships docked in the port, removing as much as 100,000 pounds per boat. Wayne discusses his work against a backdrop of him unloading the catch in the hold of the trawler Hopefull.

did.unittitle:
Series 6. Published Materials,
2010-2015

scopecontent.p: Series is print copies of four of Starr's books. Starr donated these books to the American Folklife Center at the same time as his other donations. Digital copies and drafts of some of these titles can be found in series 1 through series 5.

arrangement.p: Books are listed in alphabetical order.
